description:
My dad was visiting so after wandering the streets starving we stumbled upon this cafe. What lured us in was the building design (reminded me of New York), and decided to give it a try. 

On a Friday night around 830 pm the restaurant was relatively empty. What really impressed me was the decor of the place. It reminded me of something you would see in an old 1920s film and had a European feel to it. (I didnt know the history of this restaurant until now as I'm reading the previous reviews). 

My dad ordered the asado di tira $23 and I got the malfatti gnocchi $16. The ribs were ok. It was a bit on the tougher side, but still tasted good. The gnocchi was good as well. I'm not familiar with Italian food, but I liked it. It was very cheesy and a little heavy in sauce, but to me I would definitely order it again. Their house bread though was very good!!! I don't know what kind of bread they gave us but it was so soft and delicious. 

The table next to us ordered these fancy cocktails that made me think this would be a nice quiet place to start your night if you wanted to barhop later to the more crowded/louder bars further down the street. There is outdoor seating available if you have a friendly pup. Lastly I was also very impressed with the service. All the waiters were really good at consistently making sure that our water were refilled, and making sure everything was ok. 

Overall this restaurant is a really cute place to go. In terms of food quality. I think it's more like Italian comfort food. I would recommend this restaurant for a date, or small groups, and would definitely come back!
author: Ann T.

description:
This was my favorite dinner on our California road trip. The atmosphere was amazing. They had a story kiosk that was the best! 

I couldn't decide on a wine. Our waitress suggested a Malbec & it was incredible with my meal which was a Spaghetti Pomodoro Basilico also incredible. I hope to return to San Francisco soon & will intend to eat my first dinner back in town here.
author: Mel T.

description:
The food is lacking but the customer service is stellar. Enjoyed the ambiance and the history.  Stay away from the "fast food" staples on the menu and go for the Italian comfort food on the menu.

Price point is great for families with children. They are child friendly.

Will go again... just for the building.. beautiful.
author: Yvonne B.

description:
Stopped into Zoetrope to have a lunch before a meeting. i loved the food  was excited to eat there because the Palo Alto store has been gone for a long time. the waiter was great ordered a Claret...delicious. i ordered and was given the wonderful bread  and Olive oil and vinegar. the guest next to me was verbally abusing the woman seated at his table. He used foul language and was do loud i coukd hear him through my earphones. i asked my waiter if i coukd move so i coikd enjoy my lunch. he told me he had no tables in his section even though the restaursnt was 2/ 3 empty. 
I explained it was too loud and everyone in the restaurant could hear it. instead i psid for my wine snd left. thankfully i didnt get my meal and didnt pay 30.00 for a meal that was so uncomfortsble. Disappounted he just didnt move me but there was no leadership  in the restaurant that could have either deslt with the sggressive loud man or give the waiter permission to move me. Zoetrope can do better and should
author: Jacqueline W.

description:
A few years back I was in Napa Valley with some friends. We drove out to the Francis Ford Coppola Vineyards and enjoyed all the movie props and had some great wine with good food. I found out he had a small cafe in San Francisco which we chose to visit on this trip for Bay to Breakers! 

We arrived early and sat at the cozy little bar that had maybe 8 seats around. The surroundings were cozy and the colors were welcoming. We were seated when the two friends arrived in a booth in the corner. We were told this is where Francis Ford Coppola sits when he comes to the restaurant.  There is a rope used to block it off when he is seated.

As for the food! It was delicious from beginning to end. We each had our own Caesar salad minus the anchovies. Nice large shredded pieces of Parmesan cheese atop homemade dressing. The gnocchi I ordered had spinach and the sauce was so good you didn't want to leave any at the bottom of your bowl. These dishes were shared by all at our table. The wine was wonderful as well. We started with a Malbec and then ordered the Cabernet as suggested by our waiter. Zoetrope. He mentioned the wine is made especially for the cafe and no one else. 

We ordered our last dish which was sweet dessert. Tiramisu and the special. They were as the rest of the meal, tasty and it was hard to share. We finished the evening with a amaretto. A perfect pre race dinner in the Bay Area!
author: Mitchie B.

description: Love love love! Pesto pasta, carbonara, caprese salad, bread bowl, house red -- all amazing. Great food and great service. Thank you!!
author: Nikha M.

description:
I felt like I was on the set of The Godfather, which makes sense considering the ownership. Solid good, romantic Italian ambiance, and the bonus of history. 

Make sure you take the time to read the kiosk in front of the restaurant to learn about the storied history of this building. Fascinating. 

This would be a good place to bring out of towners or a first date. I can't believe I've been coming to San Francisco for over 20 years and have never been here!
author: Susanne R.

description:
Zoetrope is a nice little Italian restaurant that really leans in to its connections to Francis Ford Coppola. There are pictures and frames everywhere of stars and films. Not to mention bottles of Coppola wine behind the bar and stacked on the walls.

Service was nice, our waiter was attentive without being overbearing and given how small the restaurant is that can be hard. I had a lunch special salad (grilled chicken, toasted almonds, arugula, some sort of vinaigrette) and it was a nice size to feel full without feeling like you overpaid for a salad. 

If you're wandering North Beach and looking for a quick place to have a sit down lunch, I'd definitely recommend checking out Cafe Zoetrope.
author: Brenae L.

description:
After  living in the city for 4 years, I finally got to indulge in here.My day started off a bit rough since my girlfriends canceled my Birthday lunch and my reservations for 4 became party of 1.
I was warmly greeted by the host (I forgot her name) but she was lovely and made sure my day turned around for the better. 
During my time I enjoyed the patio sitting while a glass of bubbly arrived. I ordered the clam pasta which I enjoyed.
My server (guy with glasses) was very attentive and to my surprise, they gave me a Birthday dessert to make my day better.
I was pleasantly surprised when my bill came in to be honest. They staff took care of my bubbly and dessert for me. I am glad I was a party of 1 because they went above and beyond to make my Birthday better.
author: Gardenia H.

description: Delicious pasta but soooo bad service ! The waiter just doesn't care ,no smile, minimum service, we had to call them to order, call them to pay, they were speaking with a friend at the bar... I won't go back
author: Anicée H.

description:
Cute cafe! That of Francis Ford Coppola. Here you can have the wine from his winery. Anything from the dries to the chamanois and the dessert wines and grappas. 
We didn't find a cheese plate on the menu so we asked for one and they kindly made one for us, which was super nice.
author: Oxana S.

description: We were there on Sunday, September 16, 2018 me and my wife were referred to this restaurant by locals. We were so happy to go to Little Italy and to visit café zoetrope. Upon arrival we were told there were no seats and sat at the window. I'm almost sure this is where they send guests to ignore as that's exactly what happen. What was more interesting about our seats was that the two women who followed us in were offered tables. Not sure if the fact that they were white and we weren't had anything to do with it. We had to place our order with the bar tender and after 30 mins had to remind the server about checking on our food. Needless to say we will not be going back as we immediately regretted trying out cafe Zoetrope and not going to Olive Garden.
author: Padilla Marquez L.

description: This place was across the street from my hotel so I decided to give them a shot and woah, so glad we did. We ordered drinks and a Pizza Luigino. While waiting for our drinks, I started to notice the atmosphere inside. It was a little more formal than I like, I was expecting it to be more casual. I wasn't dressed as nicely as most of the other patrons. I wasn't expecting much but when the pizza arrived I couldn't believe how good it looked! It was perfectly crispy, great cheese/distribution. The sauce was fresh and definitely homemade. It was pretty much a cheese pizza and each slice had a piece of fresh basil on it. It was so damn good we ordered another to go, but a Pizza Marinara this time. That one didn't come with cheese, which I didn't realize when I ordered. When they brought it over and I saw no cheese they happily fired me another one the way I wanted it.
author: Katie W.

description:
When in North Beach, you have so many options of where to eat Italian food.  There's no reason that you should pick this one over any other, except for that Coppola connection.  I've been twice and once was a not so great experience and the other was pretty good, so I'll say that this is truly 3.5 stars.

The lasagna was HUGE, although definitely not my style.  Lots of filling without a whole lot of flavorful tastes involved, surprisingly.  The Fritelle (fried cheesy bread), however, was amazing, and I would go back just for that.

This location was apparently the home of Caesar's Grill way back in the day, and was the restaurant that originally created the Caesar salad.  Now, looking at a cursory search online, I wasn't really able to verify this anywhere, but the salad is huge, and is considered a house specialty, so if it really is the original, why wouldn't you give it a try?
author: Jes G.

description: A very cute and personal Italian restaurant with outside seating owned by Francis Ford Coppola who produced the movie The Godfather. Pictures and frames everywhere on the wall with him and other celebrities that made it very personable and historical. Food was good! We had the fried octopus appetizer which was delicious. The linguine vongole was good and then the dessert, caramelized apple pie with ice cream was delicious, especially that ice cream that was fluffy with a great vanilla taste!
author: Xi-Er D.

description: Very child friendly. Food is decent. Great wine list.
author: Sarah P.

description:
My Friend is visiting from NYC and wanted to check out this landmark. We were both impressed with the old-world look and feel inside. Cappola family sure knows how to make it look glamour and archaic at the same time. We were here during Happy Hour so we really enjoyed their $6 wine. I also tried the $6 Lamb Roll special and it was actually very tasty! 

I plan on returning for happy hour and try one of the pasta dishes to see if it is legit Italian food. Nevertheless, this is a nice Happy Hour spot that is not divey or smelly!
author: Athena C.

description:
If you are a fan of THE filmmaker of our times, being at this place looking a pictures of Yore from The Godfather and Apocalypse Now are reason enough to travel miles to get here... the food is fantastic too, The Carbonara is the best I've had in a long time and compares to what I've had in quaint cafes in Rome.
Do visit this place - Coppola fans will cherish it forever!
author: Ronojoy B.

description:
Very delicious pasta and pizza. The spaghetti and meatballs had a bigger portion size and flavor than what I had expected.

And the short story machine is a fun novelty.
author: Chadwick A.

description:
This wasn't our first or second choice of spots to hang out at, but we were looking for a place in the area that had plugs for us to charge our phones.  This was a spot that actually had those, so we decided to check it out.

The bar area is where we sat.  It's a little cramped (there is a mirror/pole behind one of the bar seats).  The bartender is always right there which is kind of nice but also kind of in our bubble.  Hard to have a conversation with a bartender right in front of you at all times.  Also, we could totally hear his conversation with another person who worked there... kind of acted like the three of us at the bar didn't exist while they had long conversations (again, while standing right in front of us).

The drinks were good.  Coppala wine is always a thumbs up, so glad we were able to drink on that.  We only had one drink before we decided we wanted to leave though.  It was just super empty in there, and the vibe was all wrong. I'm sure there are times when it feels better in there, but at that moment, we weren't about it.
author: Kacey R.

description: My favorite Italian place in town. The best carbonara! And don't forget to order the lamb roll appetizer! Delicious!
author: Fernanda D.

description:
I feel like if the Godfather visited San Francisco, he'd definitely eat here.  Filled with tons of Francis Ford Coppola memorabilia and located on the edge of North Beach, yet doesn't feel touristy at all.  Limited menu, but full of deliciousness.

Malfattí: Way more exciting than regular old gnocchi.  Basically like the potato-based gnocchi dough wrapped around a center of delicious cheese and spinach filling.  The creamy red sauce is so rich and delicious.  There were only 9 on my plate, but that was quite filling.  Especially when supplemented with some bread to soak up all that delicious sauce.
author: Adam B.

description: Loved their Salmone Affumigato sandwich, packed with avocado, tomato and arugula in baked fresh to order Puccia.
author: Jose R.

description: I love this building and when I learned the history it seemed like a place to try out. That is where it started but will end for me.  What I might consider, it was a Saturday at 3:30 so might be between shifts. Service was slow and unattentive. I was excited about what was written about the Caesar salad.  That, along with crab cakes, is what I seek to find the best of the best. This fell very short. Husband ordered the spaghetti and meatballs and I order Puttanesca. The Puttanesca was tasteless for a dish that should have taken advantage of garlic and capers. Won't be back because being in the fringe of North Beach, there are others to take advantage of.
author: Sandy N.

description: This is one of the most hidden gems in SF. I always wonder why more people aren't here. The food is fantastic, the service is fantastic, the location and ambience is perfect. I will come here anytime and always bring out of town guests here.
author: Jonathan U.

description: Outdated. Food is terrible. We asked what the waiter would recommend and he said meat balls are good. They were not. Take a picture outside and keep walking. North beach has an abundance of delicious food options
author: Maya K.

description: Make a reservation to one of the jewels of SanFran.  The menu is great and the service incredible.  The setting, filled with memorabilia of the Cappola family, makes it an incredible location.   We enjoyed our dinners and really appreciated the recommendations from the waiter.  Thanks for an amazing memory!
author: Rod F.

description: My boyfriend and I spent our first dinner in San Francisco at Zoetrope in Little Italy. The pasta is hand made and I had quite literally the best spaghetti pasta and tomato sauce of my entire life. So simple, yet wonderful. And the best part is they have a story machine inside that prints a 1-, 3- or 5-minute story for you to read. So unique!!
author: Lauren W.

description: I love this place. The burrata salad and the pizzas are great. Wonderful dining, outdoor seating available. Also, the desserts are worth trying.
author: John M.

description:
We hadn't been through the North Beach area for quite some time, so decided to drop in for dinner. We noticed that "Coppola's" was now Café Zoetrope. Thought maybe they have changed ownership (turns out it is stilled owned by Coppola). We arrived around 6:30pm on a Saturday. Only a couple tables had diners, and they sat us toward the back area. The décor is, as it always was, nice, 'old world' style. The Sentinel Building is worth a little history lookup. 
Our server(s) were both very friendly and attentive. We HATED that our table was right next to the bus station (like 2 feet away). So, there was this constant butt facing the table and the never ending clattering as the servers dug in the bin for service ware. On the other hand, each time they were there, they simply spun around and asked if we needed anything....

Food:  This was the unfortunate part of the evening. 
"lamb wrap" appetizer was oddly nothing more than ground lamb in a tortilla. HMMM tortilla?
The server said it was super thin pizza dough... it was a tortilla... and not very good at that.
Portobello soup was good, and you get a decent sized bowl of it. I could have / should have gone with just the soup and some bread.
Their lasagna special was not baked long enough, and the marinara, which appeared to be made in house, was extremely salty, and literally ruined the dish. No other flavor could complete with the salt. So, an appetizer, soup, salad and two entrees, (no drinks) were $80. A real disappointment. The highlight of the evening was sharing 'short stories' from the machine, with the table next to us.
author: Greg S.

description:
Very cool little cafe with great ambiance, decor and good food.

Filled with fascinating Francis Ford Coppala mementos pictures.
author: David T.

description: We had a large group of 19 people at short notice and Cafe Zoetrope accommodated us well. The food was delicious and the service was first class. I had a spicy penne pasta that was perfectly seasoned. Also their coffee is fantastic. Street parking. Highly recommend.
author: Jerry M.

description:
We had the tomato soup, pizza originale, the Puttanesca and the pork ribs special. 

The ribs came as 3 ribs on a plate. Very Italian service.

Pizza $18
Ribs $12
Puttanesca $17.50
Soup $6
Glass of wine $11

In all, the food is ok, but not special. You can certainly get better in North Beach! If you are in the neighborhood, give it a try just to see the place..it's nice inside. But it's not a "must see" place. It's a do-it-once place. 

If the place was mine, I'd up the food quality to keep people coming back. North Beach has a bunch of competition. 


Nice friendly staff.
author: Danny S.

description: The food is to expensive for what it is and the staff not friendly at all!  My worst restaurant experience this year. Very disappointing!
author: Irina S.

description: Never disappoints! Tried the Tirado Argentino! Very tasty . Chicken cacciatore was also excellent! Need to look for the specials of the day , as they change often so you don't miss your favorites!
author: Emily M.

description: Great spot for a late dinner. I arrived with a group of 7 and the team was very accommodating. The ambiance is quite nice for a relaxing meal filled with wine, pizza, and lamb shanks.  This is really worth checking out and there will be something for everyone.
author: Nicole D.

description: The pictures of Coppola and friends on the walls. The delicious meals we tasted. The excellent wine - director's cut. If you have ever seen a Coppola movie and visit San Francisco - do not miss this place.
author: Kristina T.

description: The ricotta gnocchi here will change the way you think about gnocchi. It's fantastic! Great service and very cool interior with a storied history.
author: Son G.

description: How disappointing - Meatball sandwich was meatloaf in pita bread disguised as calzone - really ????  This is North Beach for heaven's sake!!
author: Bill M.

description: Cafe zoetrope is located on the first floor of the zoetrope building - Francis ford coppola. The cafe offers outdoor seating and Italian food and wine. It is a nice stop when galavanting around the city and for some good people watching. I found the wait staff was not particularly friendly. You can find better Italian food in north beach.
author: Amber V.

description:
Don Corleone speaks... "Some day, and that day may never come, I'll call upon you to do a service for me. But until that day, accept this justice as a gift on my daughter's wedding day."  I could almost hear Nino Rota's music swell in the background as the scene fades to black, and the next scene opens without Brando (demanded too much money) but with Jamie W. and I entering this strangely cramped space filled with movie memorabilia (photo: http://bit.ly/1f2mH2a) and not all of it related to Francis Ford Coppola who owns the familiar copper-green-patina Sentinel building in which the cafe is housed (photo: http://bit.ly/1SmqYKs). We were surprised to be seated right away at the table nearest the front door, but it could have accommodated four hefty tourists.

Indeed we counted ourselves lucky, as the rest of the restaurant, at least what we could make of it, was pretty well packed with mostly foreign tourists judging from the animated hand movements and the boxes of Niebaum-Coppola wine being purchased (photo: http://bit.ly/1Mt8ztK). The menu fits on a vertical piece of paper, so there's nothing too fancy here. We started with their self-proclaimed house specialty, The $9 Caesar Salad which they claim originated in this building at Caesar's Grill much to the chagrin of Caesar Cardini presumably, who has the more popular claim of being the Caesar Salad inventor in Tijuana. No matter as it was delicious and decadently creamy with fresh egg yolks and topped abundantly with anchovies (photo: http://bit.ly/1HtLJ3S).

We also tried the $11 Oven Roasted Calamari which came drizzled in a basil vinaigrette accompanied by Kalamata olives and chopped tomato (photo: http://bit.ly/1TBV7I8). Very rustic, very simple and quite satisfying with the squid pieces quite plump and fresh. For his entree, Jamie went for the $17.50 Spaghetti alla Puttanesca which came mixed in a fresh tomato sauce with olives, capers and chopped garlic (photo: http://bit.ly/1CD9QP1). It reminded us of our good friend Linda's homemade sauce and while nothing could compare to hers, this was pretty darn tasty even if it did seem a bit overpriced. I decided to try the even more decadent $19 Bumbola ai Broccoli e Salsiccia, which was a big bowl of creamy richness due to the ample amount of fontina blended in.

Bumbola is a chubby, spiral-shaped pasta that's meant to look like a bumblebee. Soaking up the cream quite easily, it was mixed with broccoli rabe, Italian sausage, red wine and shallots into quite an indulgent mountain of tasty carbs (photo: http://bit.ly/1SmqPGQ). I probably should have entered a decathlon from the abundant portion I received, which explains why both of us bypassed dessert here even though I'm sure something sweetly Neapolitan was probably waiting in the kitchen. Maybe because we were famished when we came in and our go-to Italian options have been dwindling with the recent demise of Stelline, but we frankly liked Coppola's cucina. It was an offer we couldn't refuse. Rimshot, please.

FOOD - 4 stars...nothing inventive but pretty satisfying homestyle food for the undiscriminating
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...a cool, evocative space if a bit of a jigsaw
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...fairly attentive even though we weren't big spenders, i.e., there was no Inglenook wine in our glasses
TOTAL - 4 stars..."Leave the gun, take the cannoli"
author: Ed U.

description: A little expensive but bread, salad and main course (gnocchi) was worth it! We sat outside but had heat lamps to keep us warm. Inside was small but cozy.
author: Kristen L.

description: We fell in love with this beautiful building only to learn that not only is this home to a friendly cafe, but is steeped in film history as the site where many films were written by both Coppola and Lucas. It was fun to watch tourists walk in without a clue and then those venturing reverently  to the 'holy land.' Lots of photos and cinema memorabilia....I used to subscribe to Coppola's American Zoetrope short story magazine and loved the clever installation of an elegant device that will produce an instant print out of a 1, 3 or 5 minute short story from a database of 50,000 short stories...perfect memento for literati. The food was delicious, the service was warm and unpretentious. Walking out, we saw the trademark electrical current insignia inset in the sidewalk with red granite and brass. Thank you, Mr. Coppola.
author: Pamela B.

description:
This is a restaurant focused on the mid to higher end dining experience owned in part or wholly by the Coppola family. There is a fascinating amount of memorabilia on the wall, especially  in the stairwell on the way down to the restrooms (seriously, SF why are all the restrooms down a flight of stairs!).

Like just about everything else in SF there is street parking only, which means there is no parking. There's some parking garages not too far away, but you're gonna have to get here some other way then by driving your own car.

There is both inside and outside seating available. The inside is very snug as the tables are mostly tucked away here and there inside the somewhat wonky shaped dining area. Having a complete view of the entire restaurant will not be possible form any given seating selection. The ambiance makes up for this however, as the entire space is tastefully lighted and decorated. This would be a great place to take someone to impress them.

The food is awesome. The pizza is as close to perfect as you'll find in this world, The pasta is also authentic italian style cuisine, making this one of the best places for this style of food in this area if not all of san francisco itself. There is a full service bar with a deep wine selection, but the focus here is absolutely the food. 

The service was impeccable on our visit, even though our waiter was surprised by our readiness to order immediately. This wasn't our first visit so we were already familiar with the menu, and knew what we wanted before he even handed us our menus.

The pricing? Well if you can keep it to 30-35 dollars a person, you're doing great. This is not a cost effective place to eat, but man it's good.
author: Steven W.

description: Came here on a Saturday afternoon and it was slightly busy and felt a bit soul-less. The waiters continually had conversations super loudly, as if there were no customers around. Turns out - as a customer - that gets really annoying, really quickly. The food was mediocre at best, and that's being generous. I love Coppola wines (and the winery) so this experience was really disappointing. If it wasn't for the wine this would be a one-star.
author: Melanie R.

description:
The guest I sat next to a guest at the bar was rude and the bartender acted rude to me for knowing anything about the liquor they had.  Pyrat is not a spiced rum.  It's an aged rum but not spiced.  Also she called me out for complimenting her on her drink. I COMPLIMENTED YOU. 
That said I've been there a few times and the drinks are good and the food is good.
author: Thomas W.

description: Really cute place. If you like film, you'll love this place. Tons of photos of films and film related prints. Really good, friendly service and great pasta. All the pasta is cooked to order and fresh. We came here and their bread basket was freshly baked and warm. I ordered the pasta carbonara and it was really good! They didn't skimp on the bacon and the sauce wasn't overly creamy. A good carbonara relies more on the butter and egg and less on heavy cream, in my opinion. I also loved how it was so nostalgic and quirky. I'd come here again when I'm in North Beach!
author: Ally W.

description:
Cafe Zoetrope is such a lovely restaurant. The service was attentive and polite, the food was absolutely delicious, and the ambience and surroundings are beautiful and classy, but still quite relaxing. I would definitely come here again for a nice date.

Also, if you come during the evenings, you'll get to take in the great sight of the flashing green lights of the building at night. It's very beautiful here, and a nice walk from the Financial District and through Chinatown.
author: Jo W.

description: The minestrone soothed my sore throat with its rich tomato broth. Delicious and packed with veggies and croutons. When I told the waitress that I like anchovies, she recommended the white anchovies in my Caesar salad, the house specialty. So good. A glass of house red was good, too. He loved his calzone. It doesn't come with marinara sauce but she cheerfully brought some when asked and it was chunky and house-made tasting. I'm a fan of the slightly sweet, slightly eggy Italian bread to dip in the olive oil and balsamic vinegar. Yum.
author: Babette G.

description:
This is one of my absolute favorite restaurants in San Francisco. I have fond memories there.

The Good: the food is absolutely delicious. I love the Carbonara, it's the closest to authentic as I can get, since the time my Italian roommate made it for me years ago, this comes close!!! My friends and husband really enjoyed their meals as well. And no one can beat getting sung happy birthday surrounded by Francis For Coppola memorabilia and trophies... I appreciated the staff singing happy birthday and even cutting my cake!!!

The bad: Our server was personality wise great! No qualms here. Only thing was the wait times, partially our fault,as we were waiting for the rest of party to get there before ordering. Getting their attention proved to be a bit hard as well. Nothing too horrendous to keep me from returning.

The Ugly: we were seating in a awkward corner of the restaurant that placed one of my friends in direct line of the walkway. Getting elbowed by another guest settling into their seat at the bar. Getting service was a bit tough, and they kept mistaking our order with the table seated to our right, we ordered similarly yet, our food was taken to their table and theirs to ours... training is key!!! 
Lastly I asked for my food robbed boxed to go, yet my food never made it back to me. It wasn't until we walked up to a cafe, that we realized they never returned our left overs- it was a lot of pasta since I filled up on bread (they charge $3) while i waited for my food. I had to call and check to see if they still had it, they didn't, BUT offered me a free replacement 

Overall, if you're looking for impeccable service, you won't be satisfied here, but if you can deal with lackluster service and get delicious food then this is a good once in a while spot to enjoy a seat through memory lane while coaxing up with an espresso and a copy of the latest Zoetrope magazine.
author: Zareth F.

description: Great service. However, their special Short Ribs were not very good. Unless you like chewing on fat and have a chainsaw. I mentioned it to the waiter thinking it may be removed since we barely ate it. He said it was the meat cut, which I understand but not my problem and not what you should be serving your customers.
author: Michael D.

description:
It might be a Cali thing since I'm noticing a very lax service industry. 

The waiters here were all friendly, but not overly attentive. They made sure our waters were filled and that we got out food, but that about it. I think they may have asked if our food was good, but I can't remember.

The food was tasty. It wasn't too much food. They serve proper portions! Not enough food for 3 people in one meal. 

The minestrone was tasty. It wasn't overly seasoned, but the flavor of the veggies was there. I could go for more actually and it was perfect for today's chilly weather. 

The arbiatta had the perfect amount of spice! It tasted fresh although my pasta was a bit too al dente for my taste. 

My cousin ordered the Malfatti which absolutely DELICIOUS!!! It was perfect balls of spinach and ricotta in a creamed tomato sauce. I wish I had ordered that to be honest .
author: Brianna L.

description:
Coppola's place.
The man that gave us the movie The Godfather serves up pizza pies, pasta, & wine.

The strengths are in the sauces & the pizzas.  The food is solid fare across the board.  But you can't go wrong w some red wine & a pie.  It's totally the way to go.

The main appeal is clearly Coppola's association, & the sentinel building location.  His offices are upstairs.  He owns the building.

Off the beaten path of north beach, it's a good spot for a quiet meal.  The vibe is warm & casual.  

Order a pie, lick red sauce off your lips, sip some wine, & soak up the atmosphere.  And remember, nothing is more important than family.

3 & 1/2 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description: We popped in for a quick lunch (pizza and salad) and enjoyed the food and the ambiance and decor. I'm looking forward to coming back and trying more items and drinks.
author: Joanie S.

description: Went to bar last night. Super barkeeper. Enthralled by the plethora of  memories of my uncles book made into a movie by FFC. my wife bought his movie notes and we came back for dinner tonight. What can I say. One star too much. My Sicilian relatives rolling over. This was awful.  Browned lettuce in Caesar salad.   Anchovies not mashed. Bread and afterthought. (Never in Sicily... not a meal wo bread). Calamari cold and tough.  Then meal came halfway through appetizer. No apology. The waiters assistant became irate and dropped dishes on table. Oh my. No apology. We left. On personal note the Manger on cell phone hiding in stairwell. He actually came into dining room unbuckled his belt tucked his shirt past his groin and buckled up the whole experience needs to be documented as a poorly run restaurant.
author: Steven P.

description:
In the historic building, houses American Zoetrope,the headquarters of Francis Ford Coppola's film company , occupies the first floor.

There's no better place to enjoy great company, food, and drinks, while experiencing an overwhelming feeling that you are sitting right beneath where the Godfather was written. It truly brings a overall dining experience.

The service there is impeccable waiters and both hostesses are eager to make sure that the customers are comfortable,happy, and have everything they need to continue the reputation of this restaurant.

My friend and I ordered the Picata appetizer plate. It consists of  consist  gorgonzola, salame, roasted peppers, mozzarella, mixed olives, prosciutto crudo, taleggio, pecorino, and caponata.  In addition we ordered a carbonara pasta,  smothered in Parmesan. Lastly ,as true Foodies, variety is the spice of life, we also ordered the marinara Pizza with roasted garlic and wilted basil leaves it's mouth -gasmic!

Ambiance: takes you back in time. The most notable thing about the ambience is the memorabilia of Coppola's film career.

Whether being a tourist or local this is definitely a must see spot. For all ages and good for groups I highly recommend this Iconic location.
author: Zoey W.

description:
Looking through the rest of the reviews, it looks like this is a shrine to Francis Ford Coppola, and most of the reviews are based on some sort of fandom. I had no idea what this place was, other than my wife saw it from the street and she thought it looked nice. So this review will NOT be based on any film fandom.

The place is SMALL inside, which isn't too unusual for San Francisco, but you'd be hard pressed to bring a big group here. Most of the tables are for 2-4. Since we had our infant daughter with us, they sat us in a back area away from the few other couples in there. Not unusual and not a problem. Unfortunately, even though all the service had to walk right by us to head downstairs (where the kitchen is?), we seldom got attention. Service was fair to poor.

The food was a mixed bag. I really loved the caesar salad. Honestly, it was the best I've had in years, maybe ever! But the calzone was just ewww. I was interested in seeing how it would be with ricotta cheese (as well as mozzarella), but it was just bad. Moreover, the crust was folded way too far in, and there was not nearly enough ham. The wine selection was good though, and the sampler option was great. It helped wash away the calzone (that's a plus?).

The interior was definitely interesting with lots to look at. But that can't make up for the food/service.
author: Jason U.

description: Ok so I might be biased since I work for a part of this company. But with the honesty out ;) HOLY crap this was fantastic!!! Had lasagna, spaghetti, cacciatore so fantastic so good I plan on taking the ferry and coming here again in a heart beat what a great place!!!! Make reservations seating is limited but so worth it!!!
author: Brian P.

description: My favorite place to have a lunch or dinner when I am in San Francisco. My friend and I had the spaghetti meatballs with a glass of Sofia Brut Rose and the Chicken Cacciatore  with a glass of Inglenook Cabernet Sauvignon 2013....nice flavor, nice portion, great service and great atmosphere. I like all the pictures of Francis Coppola exposed in the restaurant.
author: Isabelle N.

description:
My favorite escape when I was working in Jackson Square. Great place to pass time, the quirky talented staff will pique your interest and you might chance upon Mr. Coppola if you're lucky..
The Negronis were properly made, the house red will keep you warm..just remember to not lure creepy vagabonds
author: Marie P.

description: Great atmosphere, friendly service, and good wines. It's a bit over priced on wine but a good deal on food. If your in the city, you should stop by and check this place out.
author: Douglas F.

description: For you Francis Ford Coppola film lovers, his food is just as good as films.  Really nice location next to Chinatown with excellent food and quiet atmosphere.  Definitely a stop for anyone traveling to San Francisco, CA to enjoy and check off of your bucket list.
author: Paul Z.

description: Beautiful building, delicious food, excellent service and the chance of seeing Francis Ford Coppola. Great lunch destination!
author: Alex C.

description: I had a Bucket List entry to hang in North Beach. I had not noticed this place but when I walked by it for some reason I stopped and decided to go inside. 1st the door the revolving door! I walked into what I would call a real Italian Restaurant like the ones I grew up with in Chicago! I didn't know this was but felt this is from the eyes of Francis Ford Coppola. It was early so it was quite. I didn't eat there BUT I do plan to return on a nice quite afternoon. Oh and the Happy Hour had $6 Cocktail hour. I will so take friends to this location but I see it as a place to go when you are just chilling on a work day.
author: Karolyn H.

description: I've passed by this place so many times, but I finally had the pleasure of having dinner here recently with a large group of people who were "carbing up" for the Nike marathon.  I wasn't marathoning but partook in the carbing anyway!  If I see pasta with clams (linguine vongole) on the menu, I will get it without hesitation so this was my entree choice for that night.  The pasta was cooked just right and clams were so fresh and tasty.  My friend eyed my entree so I gave her a taste - only a taste because I wanted it all to myself muahahhaaaaa!  ;)  No but seriously, it was so good that I'm still thinking about it and want to go back ASAP for more!  They had a nice house red wine in a carafe that was perfect for our group of 11 - we got more than a couple of course!  This place is excellent for large parties who want excellent pasta and Italian food.
author: Maile N.

description: We ate here on a weekday and the food was great and the price wasn't bad. Maybe we beat the system a little bit though. My sister was visiting from out of town so me her and my husband split a full muffuletta and a salad between the three of us. The food was great and just enough to feed all of us. Our server was attentive and provided great customer service. I will definitely be back again in the future.
author: Cindy J.

description: Food was very meh. I had the veal sandwich and it was very so-so. Salad of arugula was fresh but dressed lighter than dust on a feather. I had a really nice glass of Pinot Noir and the staff are very hospitable. The place is very quaint, cozy and would be a great place to hang out for a glass of wine. Maybe I just picked wrong.
author: Chris H.

description: Wow! Stumbled in to lovely, warm, place to get out of the rain and find a glass of wine. Nicky and Jacob were personable and very friendly to two strangers. Great find. The wine was great. The conversation was even better. I'd go back in an instant. Whoever did the interior design did a great job of taking a large space and making it cozy. Didn't know it was owned by Francis Ford Copula until after I was there a while.
author: Thomas P.

description: Great food and wine!  Staff works hard and gives good recommendations.  Second visit.  First time had lasagna which was great and today had the meatball sub which was also great.
author: David B.

description:
Great pasta and a relaxed ambience. This is a good place to come for dinner if you are looking to spend some time with someone while sharing excellent food.
But don't be surprised if they prepare the food even faster than you would've imagined.
author: Tom K.

description:
This quaint little cafe looks quite appealing and the food smells exquisite, however the service is lacking greatly. We walked in and stood at the entrance for a few minutes and after not being greeted, we finally walked up to the bartender. He asked us if we had reservations which was surprising since it hardly looked busy at all. After being informed there was only bar seating available, we crammed ourselves into a corner table facing the window. We sat there staring at the menus and waited about ten more minutes. 

Finally, we got fed up with being ignored, walked out, and informed the couple outside to take their money elsewhere.

Such a shame that a renowned San Francisco eatery is lacking in something so vital - service.
author: Krystyna R.

description: The salad I had was so perfect! The fennel and orange combo was popping! The bread came out of a cabinet in the wall lol! It was so great to find this little historical nook in the wall! The pasta was perfect and homemade and cooked al denta !! A must try
author: Teddy S.

description: Pizza was great. Try the one with sliced meatballs. Pasta was solid. Service was great. Definitely will go back when I'm in town.
author: Andrew S.

description:
The barista, Alejandro, was very cordial and professional. One thing I admire about him is his passion for his work. Who wouldn't when you have two of the greatest film makers of all time and their creation of Zoetrope Studios bringing together an apex of talent from all different departments of film making? If that's not inspiration then I have no clue what is. 

The timing was perfect when we stumbled upon the triangular street corner in Chinatown like an adventure straight from the pages of Kerouac. The architecture is remarkable to say the least 

After a few Anchor Steams from a previous establishment along our walk through Chinatown, I ordered a double espresso delivering an instant kick to the dome, an anchor steam for my lady, and s mocha for her father. The mocha was made from a concoction of steamed milk, powered chocolate, espresso, and topped with froth which had a visual consistency of meringue. 

Not only were the libations delightful, the compassion and humor displayed Mr. Alejandro has once again reminded me that you can't judge a book by its cover.
author: Matthew K.

description: We got an outside table for lunch on a whim, and WOW, this place is a gem! It has the vibe of a classic, "old school" Italian restaurant with some character. All the dishes we tried were great (I recommend the seafood pasta) and the waiter was professional and friendly. Can't wait to come back to the memorable and tasty Cafe Zoetrope!
author: Nicole W.

description: Wine selection is great, but the dessert menu is unbeatable. The best tiramisu and panna cotta I've ever had.
author: Bianca H.

description: The atmosphere in this smallish restaurant is terrific.The Cesar Salad here is the best I have had.  They have a large wine list and many a good variety of wine by the glass which are a bit pricey. They could have more of variety of entree options. A fresh fish would be nice.  We settled on a pizza.  That seems to be there specialty.   It was good not great.  We had dessert and a after dinner drink on the patio outside. This was very pleasant. It is a great place to people watch and relax.  The service could be better, but is was adequate.  I will definitely, stop for dessert  on my next visit to San Francisco.
author: Michael C.

description: Came here with my husband to celebrate our first wedding anniversary. We went at lunch, so it was quiet and the service was pretty much all for us. We got seated at a big corner window table with a great view of all the movie decor. We started with Francis Ford Coppola's pinot noir, which was incredible. Our main meal was also great, but the dessert really blew us away. Highly recommend this place if you're looking to treat yourself.
author: Kiana H.

description:
The food is good, and in all probability I would eat there again. However, my trip today left a distaste in my mouth. 

My friends and I (25-35 years old) decided to stop there for lunch today. We arrived right when they opened. There was only one other patron in the cafe at the time. I was thankful for this because we were a rather large party of 11. 

We ordered, yadda yadda yadda, then our food comes. One of my friends orders was done wrong. She ordered X and they gave her Y. Instead of waiting another 30 minutes (which is usually worth it) she just cancelled the order. 

Later I hear the manager on duty, tight brown curls with bleach blonde at the nape of her neck, refer to my party as kids and talking about my friends order that was incorrect. She looked over at me and instantly knew that I heard what she said and walked away with our waiter to talk more. I thought it was awfully rude what she was saying. My party was nothing but polite, and the cafe was not busy at all. 

Our waiter was wonderful. So there was that. 

Overall, the I would still eat here because the food is worth it and my other experiences were positive.
author: Jessica S.

description: Amazing place to go for some great Italian food! Pasta was great, soup was great, dessert was great. Really good for gluten free as well.
author: Bree Y.

description:
Don't eat here. We ordered the grilled calamari which came out very tough and our pasta was in a soup bath of red wine sauce. The best way to describe it was like a bowl of Lucky Charms leftover milk. Wasn't even slightly reduced into a normal pasta sauce. The only good thing we had last night was the wine suggestion and the caesar salad. 

Poor food and service overall. Coppola and Italy would be ashamed.
author: Sarah S.

description: Love this place. Honestly, I've lived in SF now for three years and this is one of my favourites! Really good Italian! Very reasonable. I pretty much go there every sat now. Great food!
author: Grainne B.

description:
Food: 4/5
Service: 3/5
Cleanliness: 4/5
Decor & Style: 5/5

Atmosphere is excellent and a great place to chill with friends. I had some good wine, cheese, and meat tastings here. Building is just great to look at, inside and out!
author: Nick N.

description:
I've been nostalgic for North Beach over the last few months so I'm excited that my office is now only a few blocks away. I had been staring at Zoetrope Building (what a beaut!) all week and in the mood for a leisurely sit down lunch so I decided to give it another try. 

The thing is this place is such a tourist magnet that it doesn't have to be good. So I went into the meal with low expectations. Fortunately I was blown away and think it might become a weekly habit. 

Staff is friendly and chatty without talking your ear off. The food, chose the Carbonara, was the best I've ever had. Super fresh. Super hot! Perfectly balanced with flavor. 

Here is to tradition!
author: Amy Z.

description:
Some of the most delicious and authentic Italian food I ever had (including in Italy itself). Also the location can't be beat; what can be greater than a nice quiet dinner in North Beach. 
Do try the gnocchi; they're different but super delicious!
author: Tanya B.

description:
I walked past this place on my way to Soto Mare and almost stopped. Didn't realize this was owned by the Coppolas until I noticed the 'Lost in Translation' movie poster (it's one of my favorites).  On my way back from Soto Mare I stopped in for some better wine to cap my night. 
The wine selection is fairly straight forward with a  heavy weighting from the Coppola vineyards.  No problem since I do like his wines.
Ordered the Dry Creek Zin and later the Eleanor red blend.  Both decent but I preferred the Zin. 
The most interesting element is who you speak to at the bar. He didn't offer his name, but he was in the film industry and knew the Coppolas personally. Had an interesting 10-15 minute chat about the film industry and personalities (Nicholas Cage, Laura & Bruce Dern and Alexander Payne among others).  Hopefully I didn't bore him.
And the bartender was good also - ask her about her tattoo. 
I will try to hit this place for dinner before I leave.
author: George S.

description: Atmosphere is on a quiet Tuesday is exactly that. A place to think and have a great glass of wine. The malfatti was gook, but not the best gnocchi I have had in the Little Italy neighborhood. Love the wine though and the bartender is nice.
author: Aaron G.

description:
A friend had been here before & recommended that we go. We were able to get a table immediately. I ordered a Espresso-tini, it was so delish I ordered another one! I definitely recommend it as a dinner drink.

The bread was not very good, it was very dense with little to no flavor. For dinner, I ordered the Linguine & Clams & it was pretty good. The linguine was fresh & cooked well. Even though we were full, we ordered dessert, I had the tiramisu & it was very, very good but I was so full I was not able to finish it. The best part of my meal was the drink & dessert, I  think there are so many other great Italian restaurants to go to in San Francisco that I most likely will not be returning to Cafe Zoetrope anytime soon.
author: Heather D.

description: Food and service were extremely good.  I always enjoy the fun ambiance of this charming restaurant.  Love all the film memorabilia from Francis Ford Coppala, who by the way eats there frequently.
author: Joyce A.

description: Terrible service. Walked in for drinks and deserts was told we can't sit at a table because it's for customers who are eating and only two tables had people in there. Waiter or hostess was not attentive and not too friendly. He said it would be easier on him if we sit at the bar.  We then sat at a table and he was goofing around w other waiters and we had to get up to get our own menues.  We ended up walking out of the place in 5 min when he got mouthy w us.
author: Ash W.

description: Sue me - I like classic spots, including this one. Beautiful outside, cozy inside. Italian comfort food menu. We were not rushed.  3.5 stars really - the meatballs needed salt. But, rounded up for the relaxed, nostalgia-inducing vibe.
author: Andrew K.

description: Pizza crust that could have been served as bread it was so perfect. Meatballs the size of your head. And spaghetti al dente. Perfect.
author: Austin H.

description: Wow, what a complete and utter disaster we experienced when it came to the overall service at this restaurant. We had dined at Cafe Zoetrope about a year ago and we had an amazing experience all around...but this time around it was truly terrible. The food was four stars, but the service would be zero stars if that were an option. The so called manager (or person in charge) was more interested in partying with his friends and staff and cursed loudly with the staff throughout our entire dinner while loudly offering shots to the staff and a few of his friends who were sitting at the bar. It was apparent that he was setting the bar very low for what might be expected from the staff as far as service goes. I will never go back to Cafe Zoetrope based on this past experience.
author: Jenan M.

description:
Actually zero stars.
Went in today for a drink, not any crowd to speak of. Took a seat and was accosted by a VERY rude employee who said I couldn't sit where I was.
I left, probably never to return.
author: Jim T.

description: Good meal and awesome wine 3 glasses for 15$ sampler
author: Clinton C.

description: Our tour guide pointed out this restaurant as being owned by Francis Ford Coppolla & also being in the same building as the headquarters for Coppola's film company, so we decided to try it. The staff was very attentive, the ambiance and décor will take you back in time, and there is Coppola memorabilia all over the place. We ordered the Linguine alla Vongole & calamari. In my opinion, the food was ok and could use some more flavor. I do have to say that we ordered garlic bread, which wasn't on the menu. The chef made the best garlic bread I've ever tasted. I can now check this place off my list. I wouldn't make it a point to eat at this place on my next visit to SF, but I'm glad we tried it.
author: Susan S.

description: Beautiful building with a rich and fascinating history. The food was very good and reasonably priced. I tried a flight of Coppola Winery wines and enjoyed them immensely. Highly recommended.
author: Jeff R.

description:
We really enjoyed dinner at Coppola's Cafe Zoetrope. 3 of us happened into the Italian restaurant as we were walking downtown near Chinatown. 

The ambiance is beautiful and full off movie photo's. I couldn't decide if I had transcended into a real Italian Bistro or a Hollywood restaurant.  Service is impeccable and as you may expect, the wines are excellent and inexpensive. 

The choice between a Muffaletta and their pasta specials was tough. I tried pasta and it was very tasty. All of us enjoyed the meal and their Caesar salad is definitely worth a try.

Portions are large and the pricing is very affordable.
author: Dave F.

description: Friendly staff and a cool place. Food was mediocre at best. We got a four cheese pizza that was burnt on the sides and undercooked in the middle. It looked like there was some weird sauce on top of the cheese. And the only thing you could taste was blue cheese. That flavor stuck with us for a while. I also was in the mood for some meatballs, so the server suggested I get two on the side. The meatballs had good flavor but felt a little rubbery. The sauce tasted a bit like canned tomatoes.
author: Yuri S.

description:
I think Zoetrope is a hidden gem. It's housed in a gorgeous building, I've had great service the 4-5 times I've been there and the food is lovely!

It's great for a drink and a snack at the bar or a full-blown dinner like I had last night. My dinner partner and I shared a most excellent Caesar salad. Then, he had spaghetti and meatballs while I had the pasta puttanesca. Both were fantastic! Very tasty and large portions we were unable to finish. 

Francis was in town, so his corner table was roped off, which was kind of neat. 

Locals? I recommend giving this place another look.
author: Kim C.

description: Meatballs with spaghetti like you expect to be served in heaven.  Service was excellent.
author: James A.

description: Very small bar area, could be cool, we just stopped in for one drink in the iconic building. The food smelled delicious, however we did not sample. The wine list was extensive, beer list somewhat lacking. Overall, I would Give it another go should I be in the area again
author: Christy B.

description:
This was my second visit here. Each time was not planned. The first time we were supposed to go to a different restaurant near by but they had to close, so we came here. Good food good service. Then last night we were in the area and tried to go to two different spots but each had a 20 minute wait so we came here. So worth it! We walked in and we're automatically greated with a smile and felt welcomed. They said about a 5 minute wait for a table so we sat outside to check the menu. Some older gentleman were out there chatting and enjoying themselves and sparked a convo with us. Then our table was ready. We asked for the waiters recommendations and we pretty much ordered all of them. Everything was excellent. Of course we all tried each others. The porterhouse was seasoned perfect, not too much, had a great meat taste with a slight char. The mario pizza with a huge slice of sausage was delish. The rib appetizer was tender and tasty and the linguini with clams was on point.
Not only was the food great but the service was on point. Being a native to the city I have seen and felt a huge change. A great division in cultures and classes. Coming here reminded me of home. Of what it used to be like in the city. Talking to strangers, enjoying good food with friends and having friendly service and no division.  Thank you for that, it truly made our night special. This will be our go to from now on.
author: LuLu M.

description:
Didn't try the food because other Yelpers said it's not that great.  I take your guy's word.  Instead I had their wine flight for $15.  That was a lot of fun!  The bartender gave me nice portions and sweet girl too.  All the wines are Coppola wines.  My favorite is the Riesling, because it had a hint of honey to it.

Bathrooms are down the stairs.  If you are handicap, I don't know if they have an elevator?  Then this place most likely won't be a good match.  I do love this green Harry Potter looking building.  Always have and now I can say that I've been inside of it.
author: Michelle M.

description: Great place for old school SF food, drinks and history.
author: David B.

description: Wonderful food, great location, easy to get into on a Thursday evening. Waitstaff was efficient and very good.  Great San Fran eatery!
author: Katie R.

description:
Good food (had cream of asparagus soup, bread, and split spaghetti and meatballs), good wine, good atmosphere, really bad service. 
Recommend the Coppola Malbec. Don't be offended if you need to ask for it a couple times. 
Make sure to remember what you ordered-- I've just watched 4 tables get served the wrong items.
author: Caitlyn D.

description:
Food: 3 1/2 stars 
Service: 1 1/2 stars
Atmosphere: 4 stars

Went on a Saturday at about 4:00. Was seated at a table in the very back corner (though the restaurant was near empty.) It turns out our corner was the employee hang-out. To be honest, the bus boys were more attentive than our waitress. We weren't asked about additional drinks until our plates were empty (though my drink was empty when the food came), and the bus boy brought our food. The food was good. Good, not great. We had chicken cacciatore and spaghetti carbonara. We were not asked how our food was until we were finished, and I honestly feel as though we were ignored. To be very fair, the table next to us asked for the chef to compliment him. Perhaps we caught them at a bad time or we were not their ideal crowd. The location is great, as is the history associated with the building. However I am hesitant about coming back.
author: Cole M.

description:
The food wasn't as good as I thought, but I thought the people that worked there were pretty effin fantastic. There was a little bit of a wait, but I was entertained by a guy who I think was the manager, two male servers, and a mustachioed bartender until i got my table. It really seemed like they enjoyed what they were doing. I even got a complimentary glass of champagne and a few jokes to go along with it. It was great.
 
In the end, I got the malfatti dish and the apple tart dessert. Both were decent. Honestly, it was pretty cool seeing the photos of Francis Ford Coppola, the different celebrity art and autographs, and talking to the staff that made the night worth it. 

Update: I've gone back a few times since. Food is still good not great, servers remember me :D and Francis was even there at his table meeting with men in suits! There are def the requisite tourists there, but this place is growing on me.
author: BleepBloop P.

description:
We came here after a day trip to Marin and found the food to be delicious.

After finding parking, we walked into the Cafe Zoetrope one Saturday afternoon and were seated promptly.   We were struck imediately by it's classic Italian restaurant feel.  It is as if you were transported to another era.  

Our water glasses were filled by the time we had put our napkins on our laps.   As we continued looking around the restaurant, we felt that great care and attention were given to creating the right ambience.

We ordered and shared the Cobb salad for $11.00.  For our entrees, we ordered the Arrabbiata but substituted the spaghetti instead of penne for $14.00, and the Marinara pizza for $11.00.  One of us also ordered a glass of Pinot which was very nice.

The food was great and we were surprised on how reasonable the prices were for everything.  Our bill before tip came to around $50.00, which we thought was a great deal.  

It seems more times then I would like to admit, when going out to a restaurant you sometimes come away with the feeling that no matter how well the food was prepared and served, the prices were pushing the envelope.  Not here!  Everything we enjoyed at Cafe Zoetrope was excellent.  We only wish we lived around the corner so we could make this our neighborhood Italian restaurant. 

Enjoy!
author: Georgie M.

description: Typical North Beach Italian restaurant. Ordered the house wine and special grilled squid appetizer; which was amazing.  The service was pretty-much non-existent and although the bartender was doing nothing, he took forever to pour our wine. After waiting to get the check, I finally asked another waiter and he responded, "I am not your waiter" and walked away.  Wow.  Too many italian restaurants to go to to ever make me want to come back.
author: Brian F.

description: I have dined here several times. The place is decorated very cool with many things from the movies. The food has always had good flavor. Unfortunately I am no longer able to dine here because they don't offer gluten free pasta.
author: Paul D.

description:
Quaint with a neighborhood feel.

This visit, we had:
Bottle of Salice Salentino 
Picada tray - Picada Tray gorgonzola, salame, roasted peppers, mozzarella,   
mixed olives, prosciutto crudo, taleggi , pecorin, caponata 
Spaghetti carbonara - Niman Ranch guanciale, egg, ground black pepper and   pecorino romano
Linguini vongle - fresh clams, white wine, parsley and red pepper flakes

Always enjoyable.
author: Gloria H.

description:
This was one of the worst restaurant experiences I've had in San Francisco. I never post on Yelp, but felt compelled to after this dinner. Having worked in the restaurant industry for 9+ years, this was totally unacceptable and disappointing. Not only did the waiters barely engage in conversation, but also seemed stoned or just absent. 

Regarding the food: appalling. You can tell it's an amateur chef that unfortunately has gotten lazy. The grilled calamari salad was tough as rubber bands, and served with underripe tomatoes...sloppy. The Bumbola pasta was a disaster - undercooked pasta, and a sauce that looked and tasted like skim milk and red wine mixed together, and not even cooked or reduced. The pizza was crispy, but lacked flavor and seasoning.

As a very forgiving and frequent diner in this city, it's unacceptable to serve this kind of food to locals OR tourists who come because it is in fact the Coppola's building and restaurant. Please for the love of god- and as a neighborhood local - rethink this menu and whip your staff into shape.
author: Julia M.

description: I am surprised that Mr. Coppola would let his name be associated with this restaurant. The people were very nice but didn't know the wines, didn't bring the food in the correct order, and definitely did not know how to cook caciotorre.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
We're a group of about a dozen writers who meet here once a month on a Saturday afternoon, during the time when there are not a lot of people. It is after lunch after all. The waitress comes by and takes our orders. Some of us order beers, others order soups, some of us order entrées, and others are there just to talk about writing. 

After the waitress takes the orders, she leaves, and a male server with curly blond hair comes by and gives us a lecture, stating that we can't come here every single month and take up space because we're a restaurant, we know it's called a café, but we're here to make money, we're here to serve food, not just bowls of soup. 

We were all embarrassed because we knew that we weren't really there to eat the food, but we did order food and we did spend money. And that's not the biggest issue because as I looked around the restaurant, we took up less than half of the capacity of the café. 

I would understand if the restaurant was full, and I would also understand if there's a line outside waiting for tables, but that simply wasn't the case. And the few hours we were there, there were many seats that remained available. 

The plain fact was, had we not been there, they would've not gotten any of the revenue or the tips that we generously gave, despite the curly blond waiter's diatribe against our being there.

Added on top of this guy's anger, other servers also looked at us, giving us the stink eye. I'm not sure Francis Ford Coppola would appreciate his waiters treating customers like this, but then I doubt anything is going to be done, since the wait staff hasn't changed since the past year that we've been there. 

Unfortunately, I won't be recommending this place to any of my friends traveling to San Francisco, since there are about 3000 other restaurants they can go to.
author: Jimmy N.

description: Just had a fantastic meal here. Great food and service. We live in Oakland and come to San Francisco frequently to dine. Ambience is great (quiet towards the back of the restaurant, which is in an old historic building). Food was excellent too. Not sure what the negative reviewers ate, but our calamari appetizer, Cesar salad, side of cooked escarole and sausage/mushroom pizza were fabulous. Service was attentive yet unobtrusive. Will definitely return.
author: Audrey K.

description: great area in Little Italy to have appetizers and wine with friends.  Love the history behind the cafe that this was once the spot where the Godfather 1-2 were edited. Love the pictures on the wall and the friendly staff.
author: Kim S.

description:
Despite late notice, we managed to get Friday night reservation at 8pm for 4. It has charmingly quaint interior.

Gnochi special: yummmm... perfect soft chewy texture and delicious sauce that we also ate with pizza crust!
Pizza Prosciutto : great soft crust but could use more toppings.
Spaghetti Carbonara: a bit too hard but good sauce. Easily the least liked.
Couple good salads that I didn't remember.
Tartufo chocolate: great flavor combination of chocolate and fruity filling.

My friend also love their pepper flakes. Good efficient service
author: Agustinus T.

description:
Upon seeing our disappointed faces as the maitre'd informed us of a long wait, a kind couple told us that they'd be done soon. Since we were the only ones waiting, luckily we were seated in 10 minutes.

Italian food it was for that nice warm Friday night.
We ordered salads, vegetarian gnocchi and veggie pasta with arabiatta sauce.

The highlight of dinner that night, the unanimously picked favorite was the spinach-ricotta cheese gnocchi. Meat eaters, non-meat eaters alike loved it. Everyone wanted seconds. It was handmade, delicious and unlike any gnocchi I've ever had.

We topped off our fuel tanks with tiramisu which was just the right amount of sweetness and deliciousness.

I can't wait to go back and try other items on the menu
author: Kinjal S.

description:
Location good. Food adequate to good. Drinks delicious. Atmosphere busy and upbeat.

Service terrible and they add their own tip. Maybe in our case that was extra smart. We would never have given the nod to 18% otherwise.
author: Pamela K.

description: Where do I even begin on one of the absolute worst meals I've ever eaten in the bay area? Is that an exaggeration? Absolutely not! We met friends at this café last night in hopes of having an excellent meal. From the very start when our waiter, Jafar, greeted us I knew there were going to be problems. He walked around like he was in a daze and had no idea what was going on. Our friends had arrived first and ordered drinks and a Caesar salad. When we arrived 10 minutes after them, we sat down and were given menus. Their Caesar salads were served within five minutes of us receiving our menus. We tried to order quickly to catch up. So all four of us placed our entrée order and my boyfriend and I placed our order for the same Caesar salad.  Thirty minutes later, here come our entrees!! When I asked Jafar where my salad was, he said he didn't know we ordered salads. He wrote it down so how could he not have known?  It was that daze he was in! We sent the entrées back which was a big mistake.  They just put them under a heat lamp of course. 15 minutes later here come our Caesar salads. I was like you got to be kidding me! We ate the so-so Caesar salad, but it was very wilted. Next, they brought the meals that they were trying to serve us a half an hour prior. Can you say gross? I ordered chicken cacciatore. I have never seen chicken cacciatore with just a leg and a thigh! It usually comes with chopped up chicken breast. It was in a disgusting brown sauce and the potatoes were extremely undercooked. I didn't want to bother Jafar with sending it back, because I may never see the food or him ever again. Next thing you know, he's bringing wine to  our table that we didn't order. What a sloppy mess! Because our meals were barely edible, we decided to try the dessert. It was at that point that I realized I must have been a glutton for punishment. I ordered a cannoli which was pretty good. My friends and my boyfriend ordered pie that was on the menu. Two of our menus said Apple pie, two of our menus said pear pie. When Jafar went to find out what the pie really was he came back and said it was peach pie! Another disaster. The peach pie was a pile of peaches thrown on a plate. There was no crust! It was disgusting. I can't believe Francis Ford Coppola puts his name on this place. I'm just a regular gal and I would never claim to own this joint. We are members of Francis Ford Coppola's winery which is excellent.  While we love the wines, we're curious as to why he keeps this dump open. It really had a dingy look and feel to it and the food and service were awful. The best was when my boyfriend asked Jafar where the men's room was. Jafar repeated, men's room? Men's room? I mean, is that a difficult question? Trust me people, stay away from this joint. There are several other great restaurants in the area and in the city itself rather than spend your money in this dump.
author: Sandra P.

description: Multiple visits to CZ.  The wine selection (assuming you like Coppola wines) is extensive.  Salads, pizzas, pasta have always been great.  Had the beef short ribs.  It is listed as a restaurant specialty.  Waiter warned that it was not the traditional slow cooked short rib but a made to order grilled variety that was fatty.  I tried and his description was accurate.  Would not order again.  Not sure what the attraction is or why it's considered a 'specially'.  Service is always pleasant and attentive.  Definitely will be back but trying another dish.  The Porterhouse on the neighbor's table looked good.
author: Dwight A.

description: This place is such cool venue. Exterior and interior are equally unique and impressive. I have a small, sausage pizza. Which, given my size, would have been easy to eat. But there was so much sausage on the pizza, it was a bit overwhelming. The smart choice would have been to only eat half, and take the remainder with me...but I'm not known for making smart decisions. Ended up eating the entire thing, and walked 10+ miles around the city to walk it off. Worth it. Totally.
author: Jody C.

description: This place was an unexpectedly nice find!  We were able to get in last minute without reservations, and the host was quite gracious.  The food was good - we enjoyed the gnocchi special and Pizza Originale.  The Director's Pinot was also nice.  The service was solid and the ambiance was pleasant.
author: Barnali D.

description: After dinner at a modest, family pizzeria in North Beach, I attempted to order a coffee drink, hopefully, to go. After asking a staffer, and then, at his recommendation, standing at the bar for a few minutes without so much as an upward glance by the bartender, I sought out the manager. In a strong, unidentifiable Italian accent, she cleverly shifted the blame to me. The place was half empty. Were I a manager, my first question would be, how can I help you? Major fail.
author: SB B.

description: Is this the best Italian restaurant in San Francisco?  No.  Is it, however, a great spot to visit with out-of-towners who want to sample classic Italian dishes and a wide variety of Coppola's (underrated) wines at reasonable (for SF) prices?  Absolutely.  Don't overthink this:  get a caesar salad, your favorite pasta, and a sampling of Coppola's reds, and you'll have a nice lunch or dinner.
author: Ty D.

description: Very friendly and knowledgable wait staff.  Allowed me to try a few wines before I made a selection   Cool place. Especially given the history here w Coppola   Stopped in here on a whim on my way to somewhere else and I'm glad that I did. Cheers
author: Beth D.

description:
So my first impressions of this cafe were that it was very small. I only had this thought upon entering because it looked impossibly busy and I was starving! To my surprise and delight our hostess greeted us at the door after a couple of seconds and was able to get us a little private booth for two in the right corner of the restaurant. It was a perfect little booth close to the bar but also with a window view to keep claustrophobia at bay.

Complimentary bread with oil/balsamic is served and the male server brought our waters and menus out immediately. The menu has some interesting appetizers, pizzas, and the normal Italian fare. We were in the mood for pasta so I decided on the spaghetti with meatballs and my BF got the Linguini Vongole. To drink we went with waters and a tasting of 3 wines.

While waiting for food we did some people watching and observed that the waitstaff seemed to be on their game for the most part. I read that some other reviews found the staff to be distant or cold, even rude, this was not our experience. Our main server was a bit dry but polite nonetheless and the others were perfectly cordial and friendly. The bar scene was interesting; this seems to be a trendy little watering hole for some of the locals and you are in such proximity to others due to the size of the restaurant that you cannot help but be part of their conversations at times. Definitely entertaining.

The wines arrived first (the pasta is cooked fresh to order and takes at least 20 minutes), we sampled a Syrah, a Malbec, and a Zinfandel which were all good. The Syrah was my favorite, although I would not call myself a wine enthusiast.

When the food came, I could not have been happier with the spaghetti and meatballs. The meatballs are a house specialty and mixture of beef, pork, and veal which were delicious and the sauce was fantastic;very rustic but light and flavorful at the same time. My BF was not as much of a fan of the Linguini Vongole (with clams). The pasta was a bit more Al Dente than he prefers and the white wine butter sauce was a bit thin and did not really adhere to the noodle at all. The clams were really irrelevant to the dish in terms of flavor and instead just got in the way.

All in all I gave the restaurant 4 stars because the ambiance, service, and overall experience were all good. I would return some day in the future; the pizzas looked amazing!
author: Mandi F.

description:
Great meal! 
They made a great Manhattan and Old Fashioned. The wait staff wasn't in the way and let us enjoy our time without pushing us along too quickly.
author: Michelle S.

description:
Ambience: Five Stars

Food: Four Stars

Service at Bar: Five Stars

Service in Restaurant: Haughty and Effete. Nobody looked happy. Three tables were occupied and the wait staff was milling around near the front door like harpies. We sat at the bar and I watched for an hour and if quizzed, would have to say that no one on the floor liked their job. Being wait-staff is a tough job but one thing is paramount and part of the job description-look as if you enjoy your work. Better if you really do enjoy it but it was a pretty grim atmosphere. Possibly a supercilious attitude is mistaken for "professionalism" but it doesn't work in this era. Also, best to remember that like the stage, someone is always watching your performance.
author: Michael B.

description:
Came here on A beautiful Sunday for my fathers birthday and  had high expectations  that where not met .

A.) when you walk into a restaurant  and your paying for the experience and the first thing you see a is server with a pissed off face 
-That doesn't make the guess feel welcomed

B.) We had a party of 8 Adults and 2 children at one point my niece's game might have been a  little loud which i had on low  but we totally understand if  that might distract  others
******BUT the way they acknowledge the situation i did not appreciate
 so instead of having PROFESSIONAL CUSTOMER SERVICE and go to one of the adult at the table to privately tell us to lower it down the unhappy server came straight to the middle of our  table( keep in mind the restaurant is small ) and said out loud in the open " turn of the game its very disruptive"  and you can tell the other tables heard and stared a little . Do you think that would make us feel uncomfortable and uneasy especially since the other table close to us had a child playing a game as well? YES IT DID but we let it go especially since my family and I haven't had a family outing in over 10 years

C. MY pet peeve is inconsistency  and when our food was brought out  the waitress didn't offer more ground  pepper or cheese or anything of the sort but the other table next to us that  were dress a little formal not sure if it was meeting when there food came out she offered them shredded cheese . I might should too critical  but the small things count especially when you are expecting  high standards at a restaurant

*************GOOD NOTES
-Short ribs are amazingly  tender ,moist ,and flavorful!!!!
-Carbonara is not to heavy but has a lot of flavor !!



Constructive Criticism
