1.People will become referrals and loyal guests if you build relationship with them and make them feel welcome.
2.Consistency
author: Chantel-Alexa R.

description:
Beautiful historic building and ambiance in this space.

Service was not so great. The waiters were not very attentive, the host was not happy to be there.

The food was a hit and miss. The linguine con vongole was delicious and flavorful. The short rib, the asado de tira was disappointing because there was no flavor in the meat and even less in the chimichurri. Apparently the caeser salad was first prepared in this building. Well, I have to say it's been vastly improved at other places so their caeser was just mediocre. 

I'd give 5 stars for the ambiance, 1 star for the service and 3 stars for the food. That averages out to 2.66 stars (rounded up to 3).
author: kewlby x.

description: I thought it was really good and I loved  the Bread!! It was so cakey and great. The Spaghetti and meatballs was FANTASTIC!! The meatballs were HUGE and the pasta tasted homemade and delicious! They had this great lemonade soda that was really good. I recommend this restaurant if u are a movie geek and love Francis Ford Coppola because he owns this fantastic restaurant!!!!
author: Samuel B.

description:
I STILL love the food here, but the service has really been getting sloppy. The staff is all perfectly nice, just not doing the basic job I expect of a waiter. Here's my tips to the wait staff for things they should do without customers having to ask:

* great that the hot food is delivered hot, but when the bus-person brings the dishes to the table, have a system so you know who gets what, don't keep showing up asking "who ordered ____" for every dish that comes!

* when a party orders entrees, wine and appetizers all around, fill the bread basket when it's empty

* check on us at some point during the meal to make sure everything is OK

* when someone orders a liter of sparkling water, bring glasses (or did you expect us to drink the tap water in order to empty those glasses?)
author: Laurel L.

description: Excellent spaghetti & meatballs accompanied with cask (cab)!
author: Scott S.

description:
Best place in North Beach for Italian food and wine.

Service was impeccable. 
Food and dessert was top quality
The various Coppola wines are delicious.
author: Glen G.

description:
After a long walk we finally decided on this place.  They have seating in and outside.  Since we had our pup with us we sat outside.

The service is great.  Our waitress Patricia was great!

We ordered...

2 glasses of Pinot Grigio-very good (Copola I think)

Insalada di Pollo-it was ok but not great.  Could use a little more dressing and a little less chicken.

Malfatii-the best I ever had!  The sauce was incredible.

Would come back again to try other things on the menu.

Good for dates and groups.
author: Diane C.

description:
My wife and I both ordered their Caesar salad, as it was noted as made fresh daily with egg yolk; a personal favorite of mine! The salad was good. It had anchovies, which disappointed me as that is not tradition as people think ("There are no anchovies in Caesar Salad", Julia Child. From Julia Child's Kitchen) and I don't enjoy them.

My wife ordered the Linguine alle Vongole - the pasta was nice, and overall the dish had strong garlic flavors and spiciness which I really enjoyed.

I ordered the Spaghetti alla Carbonara Classico - the pasta was nice, the guanciale was nice and salty.

With all the Italian places in North Beach so close together, I do not think I would go back to Cafe Zoetrope just based on alternative options.
author: Rob F.

description: Most of the restaurants in North Beach I feel are geared mainly toward tourists (and come across fake), but Cafe Zoetrope offers a much more authentic experience thereby seeming to attract more locals (which is great!). It has a very old school vibe and my girlfriend and I just love it. We recently were here last Thursday, and the food as alway was excellent! Also, at the beginning of the meal they usually bring you fresh warm bread for the table! Im not usually excited about bread, but I dont know any other restaurant in San Francisco that does that. Regarding the menu items, I've tried about half the menu, but my go to is usually the Linguine alle Vongele and my girlfriend often gets the Spaghetti Classico.  Both are terrific! Probably my favorite Italian Restaurant in North Beach!  Anyway, if your looking for a more authentic/San Francisco Italian Restaurant experience, then go here (also if you are a fan of Francis Ford Coopla and his movies, as this is HIS restaurant).
author: Matt L.

description: Although we were seated next to the door which blew in a cold draft every time it was opened, they more than made up for it with very well executed classic Italian cuisine.
author: Thomas R.

description: The Café Zoetrope is located in the beautiful Sentinel Building, in the North Beach area of San Francisco. The place interior design and decoration were great and it deserves a visit just for that. Front of house was cool and friendly. Lucky me, as I had an espresso coffee on the house (thank you waiter/barman) as I volunteered to move table when a big group was coming in.  Pre-starter: Extra virgin Olive oil served was great and combined with the warm bread and balsamic vinegar did the trick.  Ordered the Sautéed Mushrooms (Porcini and Oyster mushrooms, sautéed in olive oil with garlic & shallots) and got a massive portion even though it supposed to be a starter size and Spaghetti and Meatballs to follow. The latter were not al dente though, hence a bit "scotti" (slimy). The meatballs, Francis Ford Coppola recipe, were tasty and very big indeed but a bit dry in their centre.  All in all a great experience, stay Al Dente, FFC :-)
author: Pablo D.

description:
True tasty italian pizzas. 

We were there a monday evening around 7:30pm, the place was not crowed. 
The place is nice and cozy and the pizzas are really good  (especially the Pizza Ala Picada) and the prices are not over rated. You can also enjoy and taste the wines from Coppola's properties or others with a 3 glasses taste menue.

Definitively a place to go.
author: Xavier K.

description: This place is my "go to" when I come into town. There is something about this place that pulls me back in every time. This time I brought my family and once again it did not disappoint. That atmosphere itself is enchanting and captures your attention the moment you walk in. The food is outstanding. We started with the antipasto, nice combo of fresh cheeses and meats and the tomato relish was awesome on fresh bread. My daughter got the Sofia pizza ( prosciutto / arugula ) light and airy crust cooked perfect, best she ever had. My spaghetti with nice firm meatballs was topped with fresh chunky tomato sauce and pasta cooked al dante. My son got the gnocchi special and thought the size and taste of the gnocchi was like nothing he ever had, he loved it. My wife had another special pasta. Everyone loved their dinner. My only sour note was I did feel a bit rushed, could be it's summer and they are moving people in and out. Food came real fast. I like to slow things down a bit. Have no fear, I will be back for sure!
author: David K.

description: It's an Italian place so I ordered the basic basic: spaghetti with meatballs.  Waited 20 mins (which was warned) for a plate with two meatballs that were super tough and cold in the middle (still also pink -- so probably made days ahead and reheated or completely undercooked -- neither is okay).  When I complained they took the plate away, only to return 5 minutes later with the meatballs sliced open and cooked to bits -- they had just put the whole plate in the oven/microwave.  Have a little more pride in your food, especially when you are charging $18 for basic basic.  I walked out.  With so much good Italian in North Beach, don't settle.
author: Lorna S.

description:
A fried who used to live in SF recommended Zoetrope, and so I went on a Sunday night.  No problem getting a table, and I can see why now.

The food was so-so; no major complaints, but nothing to brag on either.  

What ruined the evening was the customer service.  Walked into the tiny front room (where only two tables were occupied) and I see three staff standing behind the bar.  Two of them make eye contact, then look away.  After a minute of standing there, I approach the woman behind the counter and ask if we are supposed to just seat ourselves.  She looks at me and mutters - "Oh, two for dinner."  

Our waiter was Luke, who initially seemed pretty attentive ( I overheard him flirting with a table of women nearby and I think he gave them a complimentary apertif).  We quickly learned that Luke wasn't very interested in service.  He spent most of the time eating his own meal at the bar and talking with the other staff.  The most activity I saw from him was when a friend of his came in the door.  He ran to the front door, hugged the guy, and then had a nearly 10-minute conversation with him about a car that he's restoring.  This happened about five feet from our table, and he had his back to the customers the whole time.  When he was done with this conversation, he wandered over to a table and said "do you know what you'd like yet?"  Thankfully someone behind the bar had already taken this table's order.

Throughout the time we were there several friends of the staff came in, who also received their obligatory hugs and banter in the middle of the paying customers, and they took seats at the bar and continued to talk with the staff.  These friends seemed to receive great attention and service, which is great for them, bot not so good for those of us who don't have previous relationships. 

So, Mr. Coppola, I thought your restaurant looked very cool, lots of great pics and memorabilia, awesome building, but you need to clean house and start over with the staff.  The place has the feel of a restaurant that has definitely seen its better days and is on a fast downhill slope.  I felt like I was on a corny episode of "Mystery Diners."  

You'll have a better meal elsewhere in LIttle Italy.
author: Matt E.

description: I had the best gnocchi I've ever had!!!  All of the food was excellent and the service was great.  My kids were already talking about 'the next time we come' and what they're going to order.
author: Pam J.

description:
50% tourist trap, 50% genuine.
Good food. Not necessarily very italian despite being italian. Overpriced. Fair service. 

That being said, sitting outside in the afternoon sun enjoying a salad or just a macchiato is pretty relaxing, worth the money and the closest to europe you'll get in North Beach.
author: Frank L.

description: Decent.  The atmosphere and service are a C and the food was a B.  The gnocchi i had was fresh and tasty but the sauce it was in was rather weak.  The pizzas looked good and the antipasta app was a nice starter.
author: Mike D.

description: This place has a novel exterior; however the food is average. I had two kinds of pizza. The sauce was bland but the cheese was good. It was a higher cost pizza than one would find elsewhere. Our waiter disappeared after delivering the food. He never checked on us. Don't come here for the food or the service - it's all about eating or drinking in a wedge-shaped building.
author: Letter W.

description:
We went to Cafe Zoetrope on Saturday before shopping on Union Square. Ordered the special Caesar which was great and shared a Calzone. Food was good, service was excellent and wine great as usual.

If you happen to be a Wine club member with Coppola Winery, you get 25% discount on the wine and 10% on the food which end up being very well prices for us.

Would go back for a quick lunch and I do recommend it.
author: Christophe K.

description: We love Coppola wine and decided to stop in and give it a try.  The wine was reasonably priced and a decent pour.  A basket of bread was $3, but it was good.  The service was terrible. We wanted to sit outside and enjoy the night air, took forever for anyone to take our order.  We had gone into the restaurant and asked if it were ok to sit outside, so they knew we were there.  After bringing our wine and bread, we never saw anyone again.  No second glasses for us!  We even had to go hunt down someone to pay.  Cute place, great wine, needs service to go with it!!
author: Michelle B.

description:
Great Meal!
Authentic Caesar Salad with egg, anchovies and fresh Parmesan, al dente pasta, fresh tomato sauce, flavorful meatballs. Expresso had elements of citrus that demonstrate freshness.  Service was efficient, yet relaxed.
author: Johm H.

description:
Pastalypse now.

Apocalypse Now is apparently one of Francis Ford Coppola's best movies.

Have yet to see it.

Spaghetti pomodoro with an organic tomato basil sauce is definitely one his best dishes.

Ate all of it.

What could be a North Beach tourist trap is instead a memento-adorned, well-priced and low-key place for good Italian.

Not to mention an extensive selection of Coppola Wines. Less than $10 by the glass. 

Things wind down early so plan to be done by 10pm when they close. You'll have plenty of nearby choices for a drink or three afterwards. http://www.yelp.com/biz/tosca-cafe-san-francisco#hrid:PYSOiaiSg9sT9dqMOYzYNA
author: Jason B.

description:
Love love love this place.... I have to go here at least once a month... no kidding.  
Here's what I usually order:

Always starts with:
House Specialty Caesar Salad, Made daily with fresh egg yolk
**oh yum and it has anchovy... delishhhh
then.. I always battle between:
Spaghetti alla Carbonara Classico, - Niman Ranch guanciale, egg, ground black pepper and pecorino romano 
or
Linguine alla Vongole
Fresh clams, white wine, parsley and red pepper flakes

yes... both are amazing and great... never got disappointed!
Don't forget that red house wine and end your night with a cup of coffee and Dark Chocolate Torte

and btw Sebastian.... you are cute! Will definitely visit you again and please don't forget my favorite dishes!
author: Mel L.

description: I agree with Miriam W. 100%.  The building is cool, but the food wasn't memorable, and the wine was easily forgettable.
author: Carol S.

description: My boyfriend and I were just there and had the absolute worst service! The server was rude, stoned and M.I.A the whole time. Francis Ford Coppola would definitely not be proud. The food pretty much sucked too and is priced 4 times as much as its worth. Never go there no matter how cool it sounds to say you visited a restaurant owned by the creator of The Godfather.
author: Bridie T.

description:
I've been meaning to try Cafe Zoetrope for years, so with no other plans or company last night, I decided to settle in there and enjoy. I'm glad I did.

The ambience is very casual and relaxed. It was a beautiful night, so the open doors made it nice inside, too. They sat me at a table in the back. At first I was disappointed and thinking of switching. Since I was eating alone, I thought I could at least enjoy people-watching instead of staring at the walls or my iPhone.

After a few minutes I forgot about that, because the wait staff were very attentive and friendly. Even the waiters who weren't serving my table would walk by and make a joke or ask how things were. I got the feeling that everyone that worked there was family, or at least enjoyed working together.

I had the Penne all' Arrabbiata and two glasses of the '08 Syrah FC Private Reserve. The penne came out steaming hot and fresh, and I had to wait a few minutes before I could eat. It was delicious and very spicy (I was sweating halfway through). It's hit or miss to order a simple dish like penne and marinara, because some restaurants can make it bland and watery. This penne was done just right and the sauce was thick and hearty - but still very fresh. It had nice chunks of garlic that melted in my mouth. When I was done I had bread left, so I ate up the rest of the sauce with it.

Writing this, I'm getting hungry again.

The wine was great, too. I like Coppola wines at home but I hadn't tried their Syrah. I'll definitely look for this one in the store. It was bold but not too fruity and went nicely with the spicy pasta. A lot of restaurants will give you a little more than a taste when you order by the glass, but they gave me a full pour on both glasses.

The couple sitting next to me really enjoyed their food, too (I asked). A few tables down it looked like a girls night out, and they seemed to be having a great time joking with their waiter and asking him about wines.

Last week a friend and I sat at the bar and had a drink, but no food. The bartender was friendly and it had the same ambience all around. However, I wish I had just ordered wine instead of the cocktail. I got an Old Fashioned and the bartender plopped in a whole orange slice, squirted in a ton of soda and lots of ice. Instead of being a compliment to the whiskey, the orange just made it all too bitter. So I would be cautious about getting cocktails. Next time I will just order a scotch or whiskey, neat.

Besides our bar experience, I was very impressed by Cafe Zoetrope. It's in a touristy area and yes, it's full of Coppola-belia, but it stands on its own as a great place for a real Italian meal experience.
author: D.J. B.

description: Was walking down Columbus looking for an excuse to stop, and saw this cute cafe with sidewalk seating. Ordered wine and a cheese plate, and enjoyed people watching. Very nice staff.
author: Diane E.

description:
Prepare yourself for the worst pizza experience in San Francisco, period.

If your favorite pizza temples include Una Pizza Napoletana, Little Star Pizza and/or Pizzetta 211, beware. café Zoetrope's pizza is Pizza Hell. 

This is offensively bad.

When we received our Originale ($16.50) we were speechless. The pizzas were cold, stale, insipid. They looked three days old. I had leftover pizzas that tasted so much better than this. Heck unfrozen frozen pizzas fare better, Wait, even plain cardboard tastes better. 

Is this a joke? I asked nobody in particular as the waiters disappeared shortly after delivering the dishes.

It was not. 

Hell is other pizzas. 

I had not been at Café Zoetrope for more than three years. Now I remember why. 

Couple that with overpriced mediocre Italian wine and, bingo, you have the perfect recipe for a Pizza Disaster Night. 

First world problems in full effect. No, just no.

Café Zoetrope is a tourist trap with no exits in sight. Run, run for your life.
author: Matt B.

description:
(See pic)

Came back and had lunch here.

We had a hard time knowing how to push through the traditional door and ended up taking the easy side modern door. I forgot how I used the door before.

The Carbonara I was was good and my colleague's French onion soup looked pretty.

Service was good but was fairly slow. This place was not busy at all at lunch time.
author: T L.

description:
I was disappointed in my experience here. 

1. Our hostess was very welcoming but the rest of wait staff seemed a bit disorganized and a bit rushed even tho it was not terribly busy. 

2. The major one...our food came to us cold cold...there is nothing more disappointing than eating out and yr food looks like it was waiting out for 10 minutes. + Not only was the food cold but it wasn't all that impressive. With so many restaurants and wonderful ones no less here in SF you will likely find better food and service at other locations - Delfina, SPQR, etc. 

3. The bathrooms are dirty. 

It's alright but it is not going to change yr life. 

The upside is it is great location and pretty architecture.
author: melissa m.

description:
We had a spectacular Italian dinner here.  First of all, service was terrific.  Our waitress was very friendly and prompt.  The ambiance is nice--a mix of Italian and memorabilia from Francis Ford Coppola's movies.  (His American Zoetrope Studios is headquartered in the same building.)  

The Caesar Salad ( a house specialty, per the menu) was delicious--among the best I've had in a long time.  I had a simple Pizza Luigino, which had a perfect crust and tasty, fresh ingredients.  

Prices are very reasonable. Pizzas (more than enough for one person) range between $10 and $17. Dinners are $12 to $17.

Recommended!
author: Augie R.

description:
First and foremost, I love the building Cafe Zoetrope occupies.  The design is so unique and for whatever reason, it just looks like a building in SF that you could only find in this border FiDi/North Beach/Chinatown area.

Despite knowing ahead of time that their pizzas are supposed to be pretty good (and they are), I opted for the Spaghetti alla Carbonara Classico - Spaghetti with Niman Ranch guanciale (bacon), egg, ground black pepper and pecorino romano.  Now, if looks were ever deceiving, this would be a perfect example of that.  The bowl comes out looking really modest, but it's really not my friends.  I was pretty damn hungry, and I still left a few bites behind.  For me, I did have a small knock or two against the dish, but part of it was my own fault too.  Guanciale is obviously salty in nature so that was a given, but it also felt a little burned...sort of like eating oily pork rinds.  The other thing was me screwing up - I had the waiter sprinkle on some parmesan cheese, but I failed to stop him in time and ended up with a cheesier pasta than I would have liked.  Whoops on me.

As for their pizza, I definitely want to come back for more.  My friend next to me ordered the Pizza Funghi e Salsicce - Italian sausage, mushroom, mozzarella and parmigiano.  Man, that thing looked crazy delicious, and that small bite I had certainly brought the goods.  The best part was there was little to no red sauce either - woohoo!  For that alone, and the attentive spot-on service despite a party of 16, this place is definitely worthy of a return trip.
author: Mike L.

description:
My 100th review! Took a long time, but I'm finally there!

Same goes for Cafe Zoetrope. Drove by and parked by the Emerald Bulding many many times, finally get a chance to try it out! I was out couple weeks ago with a date on Thursday. After a quick drink, we decided to go find something to eat. The plan was to walk over to North Beach, but we stopped into Cafe Zoetrope because it was so cold and windy outside.

I loved the interior as I steped in: railings, rows and rows of wine bottles, plus random sculptures here and there. It was a slow night - I only remember 3/4 other tables occupied. Our host was excellent, we order one kind of syrah but he brought us a glass of another syrah because he thought we might like that better. We weren't sure what to get and he recommended the Picada Tray, and the Muffaletta (their spinach potato gnocchi in rich rich creamy sauce, droolz...). He came by to check with us on the wine and the gnocchi came already divided, I felt so well taken care of.

So yummy we ate all of it! I'm a fan.
author: Lois W.

description:
talk about insecure.

friday night manager has some major insecurity issues. guy knows how to ruin an evening. when you make an honest mistake, the not-so-gentleman freaks out and patronizes the patrons in an ornery tone. he talks down to guests whenever there is an obvious misunderstanding by the guests. instead of speaking professionally and in a courteous manner, the fool sort of chides the diners about tips. this guy must be quite aware that the food itself is just OK, the Caesar salad is overly dressed/salted, the linguini with clams are bland and banal, the pasta carbonara is salty.

so he takes it out on the guests. friday night manager needs some meditation classes. or simply some class.

relax, bro.
author: Nathaniel J.

description:
Called today to ask if there was some way I could redeem an expired Bloomspot coupon I'd purchased. It'd expired about a week or so ago while I was away for over a month so I tried to explain this to the person who answered the phone. I politely asked if I could use it somehow (a credit? something?). Answer: a dull "Nope." I realize they were under no obligation to honor the offer I at least expected a polite answer or at least a canned response. But, "NOPE"? 

Had also picked up another Bloomspot coupon for three bottles of Sofia wine for $43 (listed on the offer as a supposed $70++ value). Drank one in the almost empty bar/restaurant (but paid an additional fee to drink it inside) and took the rest home. Later, I found the exact wine at Costco for less than what it cost during the "offer". In fairness, the bartender serving us that day was kind and personable (young girl, I forget her name) though the rest were indifferent (I'd asked where the toilet was). But I had a good time because of the company of my friends.

Bottom line: If you like sitting in a tourist trap (Coppola photos, dusty obscure awards) just because you impulsively purchased an online coupon (no offense to Bloomspot, they actually did right by me) then by all means go. 

I'm a local and thought I'd mix things up by going to someplace touristy just for fun. 

Obviously, a really bad idea.
author: Es E.

description: Best place, best food!  Great wine selection - came here for lunch with my girlfriend, and we can't get enough!
author: Evan R.

description:
This place was very cozy. So cozy I felt I was out to dinner with the table next to me, it was hard not to answer their conversations (internally that is). 

We order the carne asada, since the menu stated it was one of their specialty plates, it was Ok nothing special. My husband ordered spaghetti and meatballs  "if in Italy do as the Romans" we figured if at an Italian place we should probably order something simple that they couldn't possible mess up. It was close to closing time, so we waited a while. When our dishes came out, the presentation was great, however like I said the taste factor was nothing to write home about. 

Overall it was a great night, ok food, cute place. And from what I heard, the table next to me agreed hehehe.
author: Lannette G.

description: This place it too cramped.  The rude waiters knock into customer chairs and tables.  The steam from the dishwasher under the tiny bar can be smelled throughout the place.  The regulars are annoying loud older muppies.  The wine is descent.  One of the crappier places I've seen attempting white tablecloths.
author: Daniel K.

description:
I had always wanted to check this place out...the building is so amazing, I figured it would be worth it either way.

The staff were sweet and attentive.  The food was run of the mill ok and the dessert was yummy.

Short and sweet.  It is worth checking out if you are in the area, but I wouldn't necessarily make it a destination.
author: Stacey C.

description:
Several years ago, my husband and I stumbled into this place one night and it was a little slice of SF magic.

Today I returned, finally, with a couple colleagues and was DEEPLY disappointed! 

Near empty on a holiday, the service was erratic even with high waiter:customer ratio.
I went specifically for a home made ceasar salad.  When I asked if the dressing could be made without the worcestershire, due to gluten allergy, they said was no problem.  They returned with an undressed salad.  When I asked them to return it and toss it with dressing, they returned with a side dish of dressing.  When I asked a few minutes later, after dipping salad into dressing, for them to simply toss it together, they returned and said they only had the dressing with the worcestershire - I had been eating it!!!!  Then they said they could not make it up by hand after all - it was only premade in the morning, so they tossed with oil and balsamic.  Gee.  Additionally, no shaved parmesan - but the pre-process grated variety.  And not a tiny fish to be found.  Wow.  Won't make this mistake again.

Now my eyes are swelling slightly from the gluten...  Hope I won't remember this with my face for 10 more days!
author: Zeena V.

description:
My rating starts with the service level, which was superb. The second attribute is the ambience-fun, inviting, authentic, unpretentious. Third, the meal itself- prepared to order, served warm and timely.
Overall, a great family dining experience.
author: Matt H.

description:
Few things are as enticing to me as a lady than having my man hook up a lovely dinner out for us to enjoy. So when Jole S. mentioned he had a Bloomspot deal for pizza and wine in North Beach I was all ears, and we finally put it to use last night with awesome results. When we arrived were were seated immediately and got instant attention from our server, which continued through the night. Our deal included a bottle of Coppola's Directors Cut (Jole chose the cabernet) and a pizza--we went for the meatball. 

It wasn't the best pizza I've ever had, but it was good and my side of braised escarole made it easy to stick to my diet plan in a carb-rich environment. I also found the space to be totally welcoming. Its obviously Coppola-centric--the walls are covered in their wines and there are movie posters and cool photos all around, but it doesn't rise to a Planet Hollywood level of annoyance. The space combined with the company made it an evening I'm looking forward to recreating.
author: Lesly S.

description: Small but very quaint restaurant.  The service was underwhelming  albeit friendly. The best dish we had was the spaghetti and meat balls, however the Cobb salad was also good.  The pizza received an ok from the couple we were who ordered the four cheese item. Overall a 3 star experience.
author: Steve Y.

description: My husband and I celebrated our anniversary at Cafe Zoetrope. We had the best dinner from the pitcher of wine to the amazing pizza. Our waitress, Erin, was incredible and told us a lot of the history of the restaurant.
author: Kelly P.

description: Yum, yum, and more yum!  My experience with the Cafe began with a simply telephone call to see if they could fit me in for dinner at the last minute--my request was met with open arms.  I walked over a tad early and they seated me right away.  I ordered one of the specials, spinach and ricotta gnocchi, and it was superb!  The service was amazing, friendly, and fast--without being over solicitous.  I felt right at home, which is something I crave living in a busy city.  Overall, my experience when visiting this establishment for the first time, was wonderful.  It will certainly become one of my go to eateries.  Oh and MY favorite sparkling is offered, Sofia's Blanc de Blanc.  Cheers!
author: Tess C.

description: The straw that broke the camel's back was ordering take-out during my lunch hour. I have gone to this restaurant a couple of times before. Their food can be amazing, especially their soup and ceasar salad, but the service is always horrid. This last time will be my last. While normally, my friend and I put up with the slow, inattentive service, as we aren't too needy during our meal, this last time, they were outright rude. The restaurant wasn't busy when I went to go pick up my order, but when I tried nicely to get the waiter's attention (there isn't a conventional hostess stand), he aggressively stuck a finger in my face as if it to say "1 minute." To give the establishment credit, it is always this same busboy that is quite rude. He then returned with a to-go bag and dropped it on the bar without a word. I have no idea how he assumed this was my order, which it wasn't, but after 10 more minutes of trying to get someone's attention to maybe receive and pay for my correct order, I gave up and went across the street to Brioche, the friendliest place in the area, with GREAT sandwiches, soups, breads, desserts, etc.
author: Emily U.

description:
Enjoyed the food, we had Spaghetti Pomodoro Basilico, Pizza Marinara with a Caesar Salad.  The atmosphere is casual and down to earth.  They have a great selection of  wine, Cafe Zoetrope is owned by Francis Ford Coppola, and a full bar.

I was disappointed in the service, it was so bad.  The bartender paid more attention to putting away glasses than us and our salad came towards the end of the dinner.  The waitress told us that we wouldn't be charged for the salad and then she did charge us.  Very different from the service that we've gotten at the wineries.
author: Michele N.

description: Friendly , attentive staff. Great spot. Interesting food choices and of course great wines,(even the cheapest).  I save five stars for meals of a lifetime. Otherwise , a dependable , pleasureable choice. Urquel on draft a  plus for me.
author: Steve P.

description: Pretty much a tourist trap.  We were in a rush for the movies so we said ah what the hell.  Wasn't as bad as we expected....BUT we got charged $28 for a bottle of wine we never saw!  I will certainly be going back for more than $28.  There really is very little that is authentic or unique about this restaurant.....sorry Francis but even you know that Ideale, Sodini's, Cinecitta up Columbus all serve better meals than your place.  Still, not terribly awful :  )
author: Michael G.

description: As a San Francisco native, I've seen many restaurants come and go and Cafe Zoetrope is truly a landmark in the city!  I've consistently received excellent service and delicious food here!  Last time, the supervisor, Casey, gave me an excellent recommendation on a brunch item; the Ouvo al forno which was delicious!  I had a great conversation with him after brunch and will continue to return and recommend this place to all my San Franciscan family!  Keep up the good work!!
author: Martin F.

description:
Very disappointing service on an evening when the restaurant was not full.  Had to ask multiple times for service.  Food was OK - pizza was better than their "specialty", the beef short ribs.  Would have ordered another drink and dessert but the service was too slow.  Not many appetizers to choose from; we usually split one but did not order anything.
I would not go back - there are too many other places in the area with better service and equal or better food.
author: Jackson W.

description: First impresion without eating was a poor one.  My pet peeve is flies in a restaurant.  The entire dining experience was ruined swatting flies.
author: MickYee M.

description: We have been going to Cafe Zoetrope for 8 years. We LOVE IT!  This past weekends dining experience was the WORST!  I was charged $2.00 for olives in my Martini.  Service was the WORST!  I let a few days go before I called as spoke w/ Casey the Manager.  He was aware of 'the situation' and assured me he would handle it w/ the G.M.  He invited me to please come back and he would buy me a Martini and I could have all the olives I wanted FREE!  That works for me.  We will go back!  Not too bad 1 negative time in 8 years!  YAY Cafe Zoetrope!
author: Kay K.

description:
Solid service, quality food, and decent ambiance.  The inside of this little restaurant is like its own mini-museum of Hollywood, with photos, awards, and other items on the walls.

The price is good, and the location is nice (North Beach, almost to Chinatown).  The wine selection is decent (of course, you'll find almost all the Copolla wines), and the food is portioned well; not too small, but not too much.

A great place for an intimate lunch, as long as you avoid their busy hours (I went with a friend around 2pm).
author: Joe A.

description: Very authentic Italian restaurant in Little Italy. Really fun location and great atmosphere inside. Was a little nervous that being owned by FFC would make it more of an attraction then good food, but the food was very authentic and great - one of the best Caesar Salad's we've ever had!
author: Marty M.

description: What an incredible experience!!! And,the BEST pizza EVER!!! Clearly, time, effort, passion, and love have been put into this restaurant - With the perfect combination of ambiance, food, drink, and service. Luke was knowledgable, offered great recommendations and made our night FANTASTIC - Great sense of humor! We can't wait to come back!!! Thanks, Cafè Zoetrope!!!
author: Kristina N.

description:
We found the place as we were just walking past on our first night in San Fran. We decided to sit outside, after waiting for ages one of the group decided to go inside and order drinks. 

Eventually, after a while it was getting chilly outside so we asked if we could move inside, after asking 2 different people and waiting a while we got a table inside to be greeted my a waiter who was very rude to us.

When he first came over we explained that we were waiting for a 5th friend who was flying in from the UK so we weren't entirely sure what time he would be in. The waiter explained the kitchen would be closing soon. We said that was fair enough, but when exactly would they close. He went away and didn't tell us, then 5 mins later he came over seemingly annoyed that we hadn't ordered and said, have you decided yet?

We decided to order for our friend because of the pushy waiter but then just as we were about to order he just walked off as we were mid-sentence, it was at this point we decided he would not be getting our custom.

Never again.
author: Anna Sky H.

description: The food was good, we sat at the bar had pizza and soup, the bar maid who had zero personality opened a bottle of spirits for another diner and the cap flew off the bottle and landed right on our pizza, she just reached over and plucked off the food, never apologising even after we mentioned "you know sorry would be nice" very rude we won't be going back.
author: Leroy B.

description: Yes, yes, yes, and yes! Perfect spot for a glass of wine and a little food. Close to Montgomery Bart station.
author: Sara Marie J.

description:
Wondering from Union Square thru Chinatown to North Beach, my friends and I choose to dine at Cafe Zoetrope.  Very happy we did.  

The food - wonderful .. fennel salad was light, citrusy and crisp.  The pizza quatro stagoni was perfect.  The service - friendly & helpful in choosing amongst all the Coppola wines.  And the atmosphere - charming and fun .. everything you want in an Italian cafe.  Buono!!!
author: Laura G.

description: I went there for dinner before a show at Doc's Lab.  It's great for that because it's right around the corner.  So I'll probably be back.  The food was decent but not great.  The service was inattentive (the place was mostly empty but the staff was so busy talking with each other that it was hard to get their attention).  I had the spaghetti puttanesca.  My girlfriend had the linguine alle vongole.
author: Ethan S.

description: I passed by on my way to Union sq, was attracted by the decoraton of the restaurant. In stead of Italian food, i tried Mexican, their chilaquiles was sooo good, the house red tagged along was also surprising. Definitely recommend to have a try.
author: Eva L.

description:
I love this historic Columbus street building. When I think of my first weekends in SF in 2003, I thik of the building that houses Cafe Zoetrope.  The fact that Francis Ford Coppola owns it, makes it that much cooler.

Yet, what I really appreciate here (like I appreciate almost everywhere) is GREAT service and solid food.

The thin crust pizza (whatever flavour) is tah die for.  Also, I really appreciate a restaurant that provides pasta cooked AL DENTE. 

The wine selection is ok, but it's the food and the atmosphere that I really go there for.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
My wife and I have been eyeing Cafe Zoetrope ever since we moved to the city. We are both huge Coppola fans so this was a natural choice for us. Expectations were high!

We were not disappointed. First and foremost, the atmosphere and staff were the highlight of our night. Courteous, friendly, and helpful; they made a good night a great night.

Next, the wine. I'm not an expert wine aficionado nor am I much of a wine fan, but I loved our three glass sampling.

Finally, the food. The only reason I subtracted one star from my review. While good, it was not blow-me-away amazing. To be fair, as I previously mentioned my expectations were high.

Overall, I highly recommend this beautiful little restaurant.
author: Jesse B.

description:
The wine list:  A++
The food Menu:  Order the Pizza - really.  It is what they do best.
The decor: Charming to a fault - can we give 6 stars for decor?
The service:  I am guessing we had a really bad service day.  And two people really let us down:
(1) Our server was slow, inattentive, and frankly acted like she was doing us a favor.  We were ignored and our food took forever.
(2) We were seated 2 feet from the bar.  The bar server watched for 90 minutes while we received poor service.  In that time, several regulars came in and had long, very long chats with the bar server while we waited.  Two people who came in after us had a complete meal, long conversations with the bar server, paid and left before we received our food.

Management needs to get a real grip on the service.
Baked eggs - way over cooked - rubbery.  Order something else.
Cobb Salad - pretty good.  I would order this again.
Croque Madame - large square pieces of bread - no flavor.  

As I said above: order the pizza.
author: GP R.

description:
This place has incredible aesthetics, inside and out.

It was my first time in SF and the tall green building with an unusual angle immediately attracted me.  Upon closer inspection, I realized that this is a Coppola establishment. It was decided, I needed to get a drink here.

We sat down at the bar facing the window, and it turned out to be a great place to decompress from a day of walking and just people watch.

I had a really memorable cappuccino served in a mug with Cafe Zoetrope posted on the side.

The service was a little slow, as it took a solid ten minutes for them to realize we were in the place.  But at the time we didn't mind.  It's certainly a place to bring friends, especially those that enjoy a cinematic ambiance.
author: C J.

description: After meandering around the Exploratorium for a couple of hours we all realized we were desperately hungry so we headed over to Cafe Zoetrope.  My meal was fabulous. I had malfatti (spinach and ricotta gnocchi in a tomato, cream and basil sauce). Before the meal we were served very delicious, albeit small, baskets of bread. For five people it could've been a bigger basket. But I digress. The service was good. Not great, but good. Cannoli was my choice for dessert and it was heavenly. I only have two criticisms. The music was awful. Far too cacophonous. In previous visits, we were treated to lots of Sinatra. Perfect. My second peeve was the endless chatter between wait staff regarding their personal lives. I found that to be annoying and very unprofessional. So my four stars are for the food, the memorabilia on the walls and the beauty of the building.
author: Dana C.

description: Went here for Valentine's and really enjoyed the experience. Fair prices, and great food. And, they didn't seem to mind that we sat and drank a long time after we ate. The gnocchi was amazing. With so many Italian options in North Beach, it can be tough to pick one. This place is a solid bet.
author: Ryan M.

description:
It seems to be a trend these days for celebrities to open their own restaurants. Justin Timberlake has Southern Hospitality, Eva Longoria has Beso, and Ashton Kutcher has Dolce, to name just a few. These Hollywood youngsters may be taking a cue from Francis Ford-Coppola, who has owned Cafe Zoetrope (formerly Cafe Niebaum-Coppola) in North Beach since 1999.

Coppola's Italian eatery is nestled on the ground floor of Columbus Tower, the top floors of which house Coppola's American Zoetrope studio. The readers of California Home & Design recently voted Columbus Tower their favorite building in San Francisco, and it is truly spectacular at night, with the oxidized copper facade emitting a soft green glow that is starkly juxtaposed with the night sky, the bright lights of Columbus Street, and the silhouette of the nearby Transamerica Pyramid.

While I've always been somewhat disappointed that you aren't greeted with a massive poster of The Godfather immediately upon entering, the inside of the restaurant is still a film buff's dream, with the walls adorned with movie posters, photos of Coppola himself, and various other pieces of motion picture paraphernalia. The back wall is lined with bottles upon bottles of different wines from Coppola's Napa Valley vineyard. There's a small red booth tucked into a corner of the restaurant which is reserved for Coppola in the event that he's in town and chooses to eat there, and it is literally roped off until the servers get the green light to seat other diners there. All in all, Cafe Zoetrope is one of those restaurants that, delicious food aside, is worth visiting just for the decor and atmosphere.

That being said, the food is nothing to sneeze at, either. At a post-movie dinner the other night, my fellow diners and I (happily seated in Coppola's booth!) started off with a bottle of the Sofia Coppola Blanc de Blancs champagne and the Picada Tray, which was filled with mixed olives, salami and prosciutto, four different types of cheese, and more. This was a perfect appetizer for a table of four, whetting our appetites for what was to come, but not filling us up too much.

When it came to the entrees, I ordered the penne all'arrabbiata, which was met with an approving nod from our server. My fellow diners opted for the Argentine-style short ribs, spaghetti with veal and pork meatballs, and the spinach and ricotta "malfatti" dumplings in a blended tomato and cream sauce. I tried a bite of everyone's dish, and while I found the meatballs to be a bit dry, everything else was quite good. I personally think I had the winning dish, with a wonderfully spicy and flavorful arrabbiata sauce topping house-made penne, which was flawlessly al dente. The short ribs were cooked deliciously with a tasty chimichurri flavoring, and the oversized malfatti dumplings were soft and fluffy. Considering the quality of our entrees, the dessert menu was impossible to resist, so we all split a chocolate tartufo as the perfect ending to the meal.

The other night was just one out of dozens of times that I've been to Cafe Zoetrope, and it's never disappointed. Good food, good wine, good atmosphere, and the glimmer of hope that Coppola might walk through the door at any moment? No complaints here.
author: Katherine K.

description:
This is a duplicate listing for Cafe Zoetrope, so here's a duplicate of the review I posted under the main listing:

Interesting space, terrible food. I ordered chicken scarpiello. The dish had obviously been microwaved. The sausage that was sitting on top of the broth was dry and flavorless. Everything under the broth, including the chicken, was rubbery (and also flavorless). The vegetables tasted frozen, although it's difficult to be sure after they've been nuked. The dish was brought out almost instantly after ordering. There is no way they could have cooked any part of this dish to order.

My girlfriend ordered gnocchi malfatti. The gnocchi were stuffed with ricotta cheese, which is kind of an odd idea but might have been interesting if prepared well. Unfortunately, the gnocchi were soft almost to the point of being runny. It was like eating little balls of baby food. They were also cold in the middle and you could clearly taste the freezer burn. 

It's as if Cafe Zoetrope isn't even trying to hide the fact that they are serving frozen, reheated food. And that's outrageous in a city with a nearly endless supply of excellent restaurants to choose from. The only reason I'm giving them two stars is because the food hasn't actually made me sick (yet).
author: Ryan H.

description: I have lived here for more than 20 years and nonetheless never managed to patronize Cafe Zoetrope until today. I won't be going back, I think. We met a friend there for coffee and/or drinks late on a Sunday afternoon. We sat down with our friend, pretty much right in front of the bar in the main room, were greeted, given menus, and then completely ignored for almost a half an hour despite other people coming in and being seated and the waiter walking past us several times, not to mention our eventually constant looking around to see if there was any way we could interest a waiter in deigning to serve us. No luck until, finally, after the waiters had pretty much exhausted their mutual amusement within six feet of us, one of them noticed me looking pointedly at him. We ordered, eventually our order came, and then we were completely ignored again for the next 40 minutes of our stay, despite having finished our drinks and the bartender nearly brushing against my friend on his way out to have a cigarette. As far as we could see the waiters were completely absorbed with their own little world and customers were merely furniture. Too bad; the place IS very interesting, and in a great location and clearly trades solely on the Coppola name...
author: Ken K.

description:
Bistro-like ambiance with reasonably efficient but impersonal service.  Decent food; would rate it average; nothing spectacular; soup was lukewarm.  Main attraction would appear to be ownership by Cuppola; but I in retrospect there are many other options at the same price point where you'll get better food/service/ambiance.

Seems over rated in general.
author: bob c.

description: I believe Café Zoetrope started the wood-fired pizza craze in places that are not Tony's. Theirs is still the best. Also amazing is a simple bowl of pasta - I feel like I'm at someone's home.
author: Judy B. O.

description: Good service.  Food is Just OK.  Classic pasta and pizza.  I was expecting much better. We came with a big party, tasted most everything.  Not worth a repeat visit.
author: David G.

description:
I am a total Coppola nerd so I talked my boyfriend into coming here after dinner for wine and dessert. 

This place is seriously small, but it's also super cute and adorned with tons of FFC photo stills, posters, and framed menus with illustrations by celebs. I'm also more than a little enamored with the outside of the building - even though I can't quite figure out if it's "faux" old, or authentic. 

We took a spot at the bar and felt right at home with some locals who chatted us up, and the friendly bartender who made sure our wine glasses were never empty. 

A few tasting flights, full glasses, and one tiramisu later, we were tipsy, full of deliciousness, and ready to leave. The dessert was perfect and I enjoyed all the wines (particularly the Coppola Captain's Reserve Pinot Noir). 

I really loved it (and that's not just my movie fan-girl mode talking)! I think it'll become a regular stop whenever we're in SF, and next time we'll try dinner.
author: Amie S.

description: One of our favorites in the area. We went there twice in three days. The first time was for a birthday dinner. We had calamari and antipasto platter as starters. Then we had carbonara, steak florentine and a quarter of the mafata(?) sandwich. All were excellent. The desserts were amazing. We had an apple pie type of dessert, along with cannoli, panda cotta, tartuffo, and chocolate mousse. They were exquisite. The glass of white wine was ok-- frankly would have liked more wines by glass choices. Service was good and attentive. The hostess was accommodating.  A great experience overall. Oh, the Caesar salad was the best I have ever had. It alone was worth a trip. On our second visit, we had the salad again. This time we also had pizzas Napoli and Sofia. Both were great as well. I felt like the place executes well on everything. The pizzas are like what we had in italy. Make a reservation and try it today.
author: F M.

description:
Cafe Zoetrope is an upscale version of Panta Rei (also on Columbus) - a much nicer ambiance and heartier meals. We walked in last night to a practically empty restaurant. We sat by the window and enjoyed pleasant service and an average meal. We started with caprese salad, nothing unique about theirs. I had the basic spaghetti pomodoro (how can you go wrong but occasionally someone does it so right) and my date had the chicken cacciatore. 

In the big scheme of Italian Restaurants in North Beach, this one didn't take the cake on anything. Then again, I did like the bartender and server attire (a nice touch). I have my favorites and have Yelp'd about them- just go find them.
author: Meredith R.

description:
Plenty of outdoor seating along both Kearny and Columbus Sts, super dog friendly, attentive service, terrific assortment of wines by the glass and great food.  Nothing beats a lazy, sunny weekend afternoon here, sipping on multiple glasses of Crios Torrontes.  And even if it's chilly, they have overhead heaters on the Kearny side to take away the chilly SF bite.

Don't miss the scarola, muffaletta (served hot or cold), or pizza vesuvio.  All are uniquely Cafe Zoetrope & killer good!  Sure, CZ is a bit off the main N Beach drag, but I don't get why they're not busier?
author: Jen H.

description: I was there for the European style, the film, and then found out their wine and dessert are fabulous. Waitors are knowledgable and fun! One of the hits in little Italy. Highly recommended.
author: Shell J.

description: The food and wine were fantastic however the service was not so great. We got there on a Friday night close to 8:00 and the host was terrible. We found our own seat (he said that  was ok with him) and sat there for quite a while before we got a menu which we had to ask for. When our waiter finally came to us he was good just a little slow in asking if we need anything. The really bad part is they weren't even busy. The host and waiters were just hanging out by the bar.  Again great food and wine. I would consider going back. Maybe if they were busy we would have received better service.
author: Susan N.

description:
Mayby it is because I had Delfina Pizza on the mind, maybe because I rarely order pizza bc I am quite picky about it, maybe because I grew up with homemade pizza and the grandparents cranking out the pasta in the basement, I don't know, not sure but I was disappointed by Zoetrope pizza. Been meaning to check it out for years and I did admire the Beautiful and historical building with great ambiance and Coppolla memorabilia but the quality of the food, is just ok at best. All I tried was the pizza but theoilive oil in itself that came with the bread wasn't the right color to my liking, I can tell its not good quality and had no smell. Its not the pole that works there fault. They don't buy the food. Whoever buys the ingredients to make the food needs a bigger budget. Someone needs to okay that considering the prices they charge. I am no chef but my issue is that I feel that all you need is some decent extra virgin olive oil (it doesn't have to be the most expensive but not the cheapest either) some decent Parmigaiano reggiano , some decent mozzarella, some oregano, etc. (I don't taste ANY herds in my pizza which is a big non no) and even if you slapped all that on a plate, you would have a sloppy mess buts lotsa flavor. The pizza no flavor no good. 
They charge $16 a pizza well I got there before 5 so they have a $9 special, if it wasn't for that I would be really annoyed. I dint try the Prosciutto. I did vegetarian with basil but there was like 2 leaves. I asked to add anchovies for flavor, they were over salted and not stored in olive oil I could tell and that is a necessity. Also, it is quite stuffy in there, very warm. They need to ventilate the place. I get that red wine isn't served chilled but it tasted way too warm, I couldn't enjoy which is annoying since I purposely ordered a Malbec that you cannot purchase at retail so more expensive....sigh. I can be wrong, maybe I was off but the quality of the ingredients that go into the pizza isn't that good so the product isn't that good. I ordered anchovies and the reason that people don't like anchovies is the way they served the anchovies....they are only preparing the way they were told to but that is not how you serve anchovies in my opinion. Not terrible but could be better.
author: First L.

description: This place has a cool ambience, kind of old school retro. Service was good, food was good. i got the bacon and waffles. If you live in the neighborhood, definitely worth a try. However given the amazing number of great restaurants in the area, nothing worth traveling far to.
author: James W.

description:
As a member of the Coppola Wine club I wanted to go use my nifty card to get a discount and feel San Franciscan. It worked. This place is pretty compact so don't plan on having any conversations about anything private and don't expect on just walking in randomly during dinner hours. Make reservations! 

The food was good but nothing special or anything extraordinary. We did enjoy the Caesar salad and the picada tray and as always we LOVED the wine. They also have wine from their sister winery, Rubicon Estate. The service was just at par with acceptable (for 3 waiters and a small place it seemed as if they were a bit flustered during dinner hours). The ambiance is so cool. You feel like Coppola's at the next table or maybe just upstairs. His presence is known and it's really special to sit and hang out. Come here for the experience, small bites and of course wine, not the entrees. 

Oh and if you're a native San Franciscan like myself be prepared to be moderately annoyed by the tourists who speak NO english and tend to be rude. We sat between a French and German couples who definitely didn't read the American etiquette part of their tourist books.
author: Kristen R.

description:
The food is not very good here.  It's canned tomato saucified food with little love or flare given the amount you pay.

Ultimately, you are paying for the historical building that you are eating in: yes, that tall ancient sea green building that makes one wonder: "how is that building going to stay up when the next major earthquake hits?"

In fact, the building goes back to the 1906 Earthquake and has a fascinating history.  The Kingston Trio used to record music in this building, and, the building was where the sound mixing for "Apocalypse Now!" was done.  The Godfather's very own  Francis Ford Coppola has owned this building since the 70s.

The interior has what I believe to be an Art Deco vibe.  Lots of checker this'es and thats.

Imagine food sold at the Spaghetti Factory, and then double the prices.  Now you see why I can only give this place two Stars.

When you go there, because I recommend you try it at least once, ask for information on the history of the building.  You can also look it up on line if you Google "The Sentinal Building."  There are many very interesting artifacts.  But there are also very interesting artifacts at Planet Hollywood or the Hard Rock Cafe.
author: Tony U.

description: The worst restaurant I've ever been in my life. i tell and you can judge. It was 10 of us and we were looking for a cafe to spend some time and eat some food before we hit the road to Sacramento. We split into to table of 5 people we all ordered different type of pizzas and one of my friends ordered a glass of wine. The waiter was high on most probably weed and when he brought the napkin wrapped forks and spoons, he dropped them. Second he brought my friend's glass of wine but he somehow hit the glass to the table that it got chipped on the side. One of my friends and I , we ordered pizza Napoli and it was super salty and the crust was dry and I couldn't eat the edges of the crust because it was all burned. Then the brought the gratuity included bill and they charged us almost $30 for tips. I thinks it wasn't cool that they didn't separate the bill. it was kind of outrageous.  Anyway, I got the experience not to go there anymore. I had to give at least one star while i wish I had the o star option instead.
author: Ehsan S.

description:
Great service and the fennel salad was really great. The pizza was meh. Tried the Pizza Sofia because it's one of my favorite combos - proscuitto and arugula - but it fell flat. Much better options in the area.

Really enjoyed the feel and design of the spot though. Great little cafe.
author: Francesca F.

description: Amazing food, great wine, cute waiters and bartender....what more could you ask for???
author: Samantha J.

description:
I've only had good, fun experiences here and great food.  I love the building itself, which I used to love even before Coppola bought it.  I really admire how he spruced up the old place and added dramatic lighting.  And the cafe, which I believe is technically not "Cafe Niebaum Coppola", but really "Cafe Zoetrope" named after Coppola's production company (http://www.zoetrope.com/) and literary magazine (http://www.all-story.com/), is a great place to go and has a very authentic european feel inside (I love the bathroom!)

One night they sat us in Coppola's booth (sectioned off by a red velvet rope), another night we enjoyed our meal outside where we were (amazingly) warm even though it was the middle of a San Francisco summer, and a third night I almost ran into a light post when we exited the cafe because Francis (if I may be so bold as to call you by your first name?) was sitting outside nonchalantly typing away on his very large laptop.  It's truly an experience.
author: Cassidy P.

description:
Come here for the atmosphere, the excellent deserts or the illy coffee. 

Spaghetti and meatballs were nothing special.
author: Christian S.

description: I was pretty disappointed with this place, unfortunately. My husband and I were hungry after getting into SF and decided to try this place on a whim. On a rare occasion, I was actually craving pasta enough to order it, and saw that they had spaghetti carbonara (one of my favorite pastas). We ordered this dish along with a couple of others. The pasta was sooo heavy and creamy, I couldn't have more than 3 bites. I know I'm super picky about my carbonara - just read my other posts, but this dish disappointed me greatly. A true carbonara has NO cream in it and it's actually pretty light. One of our other dishes, a side of meatballs, must have been forgotten about because we never got them. All in all, not the best dining experience!
author: Stella Y.

description: best meatballs in town.  pasta perfect...al dente the way the Godfather intended.  our favorite Italian.
author: Maida T.

description:
Update - took some friends from England here last weekend, It's still great, Dennis still plays, and the picada tray can't be beaten! 
if you like Copolla's wine but you're on a budget, there's actually great value in the House Red.
author: Steve B.

description:
We didn't eat here, just popped in for some late night coffee and cocktails

Great coffee at the bar, friendly bartender.  I also enjoyed my scotch.  BF enjoyed his.  Little pricy (but it's SF and a tourist trap.. so justified I suppose)  

Lots of fun things to look at on the walls.   We had a nice time, and if in the area, would be back for a late night drink.  Maybe a nibble too, because the food and desserts we did see come out, looked very nice.
author: Samanta V.

description:
I think I found a new favorite lunch spot when I'm in the city!
One of my friends recommended this place because he liked their espresso, and it was indeed delicious. It had a bold, rich flavor. I also had a latte, it too did not disappoint. I ordered the Penne all' Arrabiata with some chicken on the side and it was great. The penne was a simple dish but it packed plenty of flavor. My friends ordered the Chilaquiles and Pizza Luigino, also hits. They were gobbled up very quickly! Okay, they were guys, so naturally they eat fast (aka, inhale their food) but they were raving about it. The boys were also very thirsty and they needed a lot of refills on their water, which the staff quickly refilled, a plus.

I loved the decor and laid back environment. The walls were filled with mementos from Francis Coppola's films, travels and perhaps inspirations. The music played included jazz, Ray Charles, and a song from the soundtrack for Apocalypse Now. The waiters were handsome, well-dressed, polite and accommodating. If you like a place that is quiet and slow paced , this might be worth your while.
author: Jasmine M.

description:
***Birthday Post***

The last time I ate here was when it was named "Cafe Niebaum Coppola" (a few years back). This restaurant is owned by Francis Ford Coppola, and they serve a ton of his wine. When I went here when I was younger the place was described to me simply. When Francis is in town he needed a place to have a good meal where he could sit and relax so he bought up the old building and turned it into a wonderful cafe. His favorite place to sit is on the Kearny side of the building all the way down. It's a very sheltered little seat, and a lunch outdoors is terrific.

It was just a few hours before my birthday when we entered the restaurant. I sat down and asked the waiter for some wine with dinner, he made a suggestion of a red and I agreed. He brought the wine over and it was fantastic!

We were nibbling on the bread as we poured over the menu, and ultimately decided on the Quattro Formaggi (Four chesse) and Al Proscuitto (Proscuitto and mushrooms) pizzas.

They came back in about twenty minutes, and we began to dissect them. The Quattro Formaggi is a delicate balance of four exquisite italian cheeses, on a wonderful crust with delicious tomato sauce. The al Proscuitto is a white pizza with mushrooms and Proscuitto. Absolutely delicious. Great tasting Proscuitto, funghi to die for and a perfectly cooked crust. The wine was a perfect compliment.

All in all a great meal in a spectacular atmosphere. I do feel the need to point out that the music was very interesting: vacillating between Ice Cube and Spanish guitar is not how I envisioned my meal, but it worked :).

Tl;DR: Dope pizza, great atmosphere, awesome wine.
author: Joshua G.

description: The food was great, but the service was the best. We had a reservation and when we checked in they called us by our names. Fernando, had our table ready with a flower that I had asked at the time of the reservation.
author: Alberto G.

description:
This place is a pretty solid little number right on the edge of fidi, north beach and chinatown, well at least in my mind thats where its at. We split a few items between three of us....... pizza, clams with linguine, and this ricotta wrapped gnocchi special thing, meatball for an app and a caesar salad. All and all it was good. I liked every dish and the pizza was really good and its hard to find good pie out west. We actually live near the other coppola restaurant and we like that one as well. 

It can get pretty busy in here so service can lag a bit and the seating for us was a little tight but a nice stranger slid over and made room which was really cool of her. Also it made me realize I need to eat at House of Nanking! I was staring out the window as we dined and that place rocked a 20 person line in the RAIN! Their food must be banging Im headed there next.
author: Michael B.

description:
We went there on a Tuesday night. There were people there, but it was not busy, so there's no excuse for the poor service. It took three tries to get coffee.
My date's food was kind of meh. Nothing to write home about. The wine flight (samples of three wines) were also kind of blah.
I ordered the special, which was supposed to be a "porterhouse steak." Granted, the price was only $20. 
What I got was a thin, tough gristley t-bone steak, like you'd get at Denny's, except at Denny's it would have come with a couple eggs, hash browns, toast and coffee for $14.95 (instead of 1oz of spinach) and I wouldn't have had to wait 20 minutes for the coffee.

On the whole, we would have been happier with Denny's.
author: Michael H.

description:
I wasn't even going to review this restaurant when I came here a year ago.  I made the mistake of coming here recently.  I post this review to remind myself never to come here again (no matter how convincing she may be, I am not that desperate)--there are better restaurants around the neighborhood with better food, with better service, with better seating, with better wine...Do not let its prime location lure you in like a siren song! 

How will I ever wash away this taint on my soul?  Who will ever give me the 72 minutes and 43 seconds of my life back?  / wrist
author: Billy C.

description: Cafe Zoetrope is on the 1st floor of the sentinel building built in 1907 and is on the corner of Kearny and Columbous. This place is awesome, there are 30 some of Coppola's wine here for sale and to drink. Pictures of Francis and George Lucas are all over the place. They have a brick pizza oven and good pizza, their pasta is amazing spaghetti and meat balls, penne arribabta, and arguably the best chicken ceasar in the city. Francis graces the patrons with his presence around once month if your lucky enough to run into him he's very nice and relaxed. I recommend this place to all my friends as my favorite Italian restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Cameron P.

description:
WOW... what an epic experience! 

this is a not to miss cafe in SF and my new favorite spot... the food was "fantastico"... you gotta try the meatballs...
author: Doug S.

description:
Molto disappointment.

Filthy bathrooms, wafting musty garbage smell,
bad food, crappy bread, so-so wine.

OK service, trying to do its best in a bad situation.

Over the years, I've come here maybe 5-6 times.
It used to be great!

Unbelievable what a cheapo crap-pile it's become.
I don't understand how this happens.
From super-high quality delicious ten (?) years ago to hopeless bottom of the 
barrel beginner-Denny's -line-cook level tonight.

For the tasteless  tourists, I guess.

What a shame. Someone up there doesn't give a sh-t.
author: harmonia b.

description: After House of Nanking, dropped by here for some desert. Got this chocolate thing, I forgot what it's called but it was pretty good. We ended up having drinks here too. Bartender was really nice, cute too. He made his own little concoction, no name, but was good. The staff was cool. It just smelled a little funky because they didn't take the old christmas wreath down. A-OK place just to hang afterwork.
author: Tam T.

description: Went again, this time with the fam.  Great meal, service, wine, . . . .  The one pasta dish was a bit too cheesy, but that was a minor matter.  Good choice, again.
author: Russell R.

description:
The look of the Sentinel Building has always excited me more than the food served here.

Not bad, but certainly not memorable either.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Sometimes, it's the people that make the place ;)  You know, where "everybody knows your name" kinda style.

The staff is so super friendly and inviting, the place just exudes charm.  Trent, my personal bartender, was very knowledgeable about the wine section and I found that to be the case with all the staff in general.

Now don't get me wrong, the food, wine, and service were all lovely too.  The caperese salad and vegefied version of the cesar salad were both tasty.  And yes, it may be a tourist trap by way of it's location.  But hey, if you're a local or a tourist in the area, why not?
author: Angella S.

description: I love this place! It's been easily 5 yrs since we've been here yet the bartenders still recognize us and give amazing pours of California's and Italy's greatest wines. We will always come back here when we are in San Francisco
author: Melissa J.

description:
I didn't know Francis Ford Coppola owned a restaurant until I seen Fog City Mavericks. I saw the documentary over a year ago and ever since I found out he owned an Italian restaurant, I told myself next time I'm in San Francisco, I'm going there 

The building itself is unique and it has its landmark symbol to the downtown area. I must say, I was surprised to find out it was a small restaurant. It gets crowded during the evening and night time. 

My gf and I had to wait about fifteen minutes because there wasn't any tables available and we didn't want to eat our meals outside so we didn't mind waiting. While we were waiting, an employee brought us a complementary wine. I thought that was nice just to keep us a bit warm with some house wine. 

We decided to order just one pizza and share it. We agreed on ordering the Pizza Quattro Stagioni. The pizza did come out fairly quick so I was happy about that. The pizza was good, however, it did have a complete different flavor to it that I have never experienced in my life. The olives really gave it a twist. It was a good experience and I wasn't too fond of it but it was good. Too bad I wasn't starving, otherwise I would have ordered two pizzas and an appetizer. 

Our pizza came out to $14 which I didn't think it was too bad. It is a restaurant in downtown and it has the Coppola name to it as well. For the size and unique style of Italian pizza, it was a reasonable price. 

I liked the way I felt inside. All the portraits, memorabilia, dimmed lighting, tone of the room, the vibe I got from all the customers enjoying themselves made it a great warm atmosphere to be in. If I lived in San Francisco, I would love to stop by here on the weekend, have some drinks with some friends and then head out to some clubs. It just has that feeling to it where you want to be with a good size group of friends, have some great wine and laughs. 

I'm definitely stopping by again next time I'm in Frisco. I'm going to have to come in with a much bigger appetite and explore some new wines.
author: Alexis D.

description: Worst turd ever. I casually dipped into this quaint cafe due to a sudden bowel trigger while shopping in China town. Journey came on the radio, and boom. Had to go. A friend suggested zoetrope because its clean and quiet. Oh! And it has wine. The staff.... Eh. Kind of indifferent. When I asked the server where I could score some opium and high school girls, he wasn't very helpful. He did, however mention that coppola himself might pop in later. I really can't stand name droppers. Really? So, after he was done yapping about coppola, I made my way downstairs to the toilet. I was nervous that coppola himself might barge in, so I tried to pinch it quickly. I couldn't relax and was forced to wrap it up. I left feeling uneasy, unsatisfied and unsure. Other than that I love the place.
author: Anna B.

description:
Came here for lunch last week on a short trip into the city. Service was mediocre at best & it was not crowded. Ordered $18.00 chicken cacciatore, pizza & the special of the day - a pasta with a gorgonzola sauce. Table bread came out almost 20 min after getting seated, which we thought was odd since our lunch should be coming out soon, right? Well, our food ended up taking a loooong time to come out, and 2 of the 3 dishes came out cold. On top of that, the chicken in the cacciatore was very dry, and the "lunch special" was certainly nothing special. After voicing our displeasure (have NEVER sent a food item back...this was a 1st!) they did take the cacciatore off the bill & even offered to take off the pizza. We let them know we were not trying to get free food, and our son was eating the pizza anyway - cold or not - since it was after 1pm at this point.
Super bummed...wanted a good Italian lunch & left hungry and annoyed.
author: SD K.

description:
Recently ate there for the first time and I'll be going back again. Had a late lunch of Quarter Muffaletta sandwich, chicken noodle soup (with penne rigate as the noodles), and a glass of the Coppola '11 Pinot Grigio. All very good. 

I've had a Muffaletta at Central Grocery in New Orleans, supposedly the birthplace of the Muffaletta, and Zoetrope's was just as good.   The Pinot Grigio's crispness and long spicy finish perfectly matched the sandwich's tangy olive salad component. 

Very friendly staff, at least one of whom is a native Italian speaker. And yes, there were tourists, but they were from Italy (and therefore are Italian cuisine experts) and they took the time to complement the staff on the food.
author: Boso Z.

description: The building had lots of character and the ambiance was lively and fun.  Reminiscent of many of the cafes I have visited in Europe.  The pizza was authentic and fresh - our party had two different kinds and liked both.  One of us had a chicken dish with sausage and artichoke, which was the special, and thought it was excellent.  The cocktails were standard, but fine - I understand their focus is wine, but we did not have any.  The desserts were the best part - the panna cotta was fabulous!  We did not have pasta, but after seeing the spaghetti and meatballs delivered to the table next to us, I definitely want to try it!  I think I will be back.  The service was on the slower side, but very friendly and professional.
author: Stacey J.

description:
Situated on the street level of one of the most gorgeous buildings in San Francisco, CAFE ZOETROPE is definitely one of my go-to spots! 

If you're hunkering for something both comforting and borderline hearty --- definitely pair up the Mulfatti with the special Argentine style beef dish. The mulfatti with melt in your mouth and the combination of ricotta and spinach makes it worth the hell of finding parking just to experience this.  The crisp chunks of beef on the bone beg to be dipped in the slightly spicy chimichurri sauce.

The staff is s'WONDERFUL!!! I gotta credit Trent for really hooking us in on a regular basis. He and Lidia know how to go that extra mile to keep us smiling inside-out each and every visit!
author: BrasilPo P.

description: I did not plan to eat here but the hotel restaurant was closed and the much better pizza place up the street had a huge wait. I wish I had read yelp before going. My colleague had order a pizza which he had no complaints with and I unfortunately ordered the house specialty asado de tira. When ordering the asado I specifically asked the waiter well done (he should have enquired), to which he appeared to write something down for the order and had a quite dismissive look which should have been my clue. The steak arrived medium rare, the waiter was no where to be found luckily I was able to get the attention of who I believe is the owner and she sent it back for more cooking. The meat though tasty was not very lean. We also ordered two caipirinhas which were ok but not really special. The small fly that landed in my drink did not really like it, as it died on contact (at least it was not a weak drink!). We did not order dessert, but the cannolis looked good. I will not return.
author: Andres L.

description:
Although it is in the heart of tourist-land I thought this restaurant would be good quality given the price and the Coppola name.

A few days later I had the shock of my life when I realized they'd forged the check to add a higher tip than I had left them.  Fortunately when disputed they backed down to the original charge. 

As to my experience there: 

Service - very slow at taking our order.  Pretty much ignored us and chatted to themselves or their friends.  

The Appetizer arrived before wine.  I don't think I've ever had that before in all my years of eating out!

During the appetizer the main courses arrived which they tried to just dump on us too.  

I sent them back til we finished our appetizers and of course this meant that when my Pizza arrived for the 2nd time it was completely burnt.
