Sadly enough, the food (except the Pizza) was actually quite tasty, it was just the service and experience that left us with the bad taste.
author: mark b.

description: I bought a deal on Bloomspot. Had a Director's cut Zinfandel, and a pizza. The wine was incredible. The pizza was good, not great (I wish the pizza was better, but it was good). We went there in the middle of  beautiful sunny afternoon, got the best booth in the house (according to the manager), and it was, a round booth in the back dining room. Our waiter was also excellent. OK, it was a real romantic afternoon, so my rating is about the ambiance, the wine, and my companion. The waiter was attentive, but read the cues, and gave us our space.
author: Jewel L.

description:
i love this place! hidden little gem! great pizza, salads, service and director's cut cab alex valley....yummmmmmm!!!! 
i love any restaurant that has incredible service, food, wine and ambience. i will tell everyone to visit. love love love!!!
author: Audrey S.

description: If you'd like to avoid a crowded happy hour bars, this is a place to be. Nice small restaurant, not packed, good wine and appetizers. We ordered 3 appetizers and they turned out to be our dinner with good wine. Oh, I had panna cotta, too. It was delish.
author: Yoko S.

description: Very informative and passionate staff, great food and the pitcher of house wine was a great deal!!
author: Mike M.

description:
Really Loved Cafe Zoetrope so much it forced me to write a review!
First it is gorgeous! Not that it really makes a difference in the food but some food for the eyes in never a bad thing ;)  The Bread was great and Caesar salad was light and crisp with a great house dressing!  But the big winner is the Pizza Sophia! 
My fiancé and I dropped in for a light lunch and we were blown away by this pizza! So good we got some to go and snack on later!
Great lunch spot!
author: Beverly P.

description: We went there for lunch it was the most frustrating meal ever. The waiters were super rude and annoyed which made us feel uncomfortable. The food was ok they messed or order few time. However I would give the food a 2.5 stars and 0 for the service. Would I go back there again? Of course NO.
author: Emanula M.

description:
I believe that Yelp, with all its wondrous capabilities, can also hinder restaurants.  Some places are so highly rated that you expect nothing less than food fitting for the Olympians.  Sometimes going into a restaurant with that mindset can skew your tastebuds.  As a result, it is refreshing to enter a domain with no previous knowledge and just let your tastebuds go on a blind date.  There is a certain joy of meandering around, choosing a place to eat on an impulsive whim.  

It was one of my good friend's bdays, who happened to have just broken up with his gf who didn't even wish him a happy birthday.  That witch!!!  A broken heart requires an obligatory shoulder to cry on and some sustenance in one's stomach.  Walking through the FiDi, haf-listening, half-day dreaming, we ended up at North Beach.  Seeing a bustling Italian place, we entered Cafe Zoetrope.  A waitress immediately seated us and delivered our orders, speaking in what seemed like an authentic Italian accent.  Shriveling my heard around, I saw many old pictures on the wall and learned that this restaurant was owned by Francis Coppola.  I ordered the Pizza Quattro Formaggi (tomatoe, gargonzola, fontina, teleggio and mozerella) while said chum ordered the spaghetti.  Our food took a while to come out so I just dined on bread while I listened to my buddy's tale of woe.  Our waitress was very gracious, even alerting me when my jacked slipped off the backing of the chair onto the floor, re-racking for me.  I wish I could say the same for the food, which I found very lackluster.  I had no complaint about the wait; the restaurant was semi-crowded and I know home-style Italian food takes a little longer.  The pizza tasted like a very thin cheese pizza.  It was visually appealing with the thin crust I like and devoid of all that dripping grease that your household pizzerias have, however, the taste wasn't that much different than your run of the mill cheese pizza.  I tried my friend's spaghetti and while you could tell the to tomatoes were very fresh, it just tasted ordinary.  A meatball would have helped.  It is quite a bummer to eat a plateful of just pasta and tomato sauce.  The dish was also quite small for 15 greenbacks.  While I can see this place as being trendy and a nice plan to share a glass of wine, Cafe Zoetrope's food is painfully average and you might as well go to Olive Garden and save yourself a couple bucks.
author: Brian V.

description:
favorite meatball...well...anywhere!

and i for one find it very cool to walk into copola's cafe and sometimes find the man himself sitting with a paper and some tirimisu two tables down.
author: Daniel H.

description:
Food was decent, nothing to write home about though. The service: meh. Food took way too long and we waited 15 minutes for mojitos, which were the single best thing we had. For dinner we had an arugula covered pizza w prociuto that had way too much arugula. After drizzling olive oil over the pizza it was pretty damned good.  We also had a clam linguine pasta that desperately needed red pepper flakes, parmesean, salt and pepper. 

In short, we had to do way too much work to get our food where it needed to be. If you're looking for kick ass Italian in North Beach, keep looking. I suggest starting at e tutto quo. Much better food, service and atmosphere for a similar price point. Long story short: I would not go here again.
author: Alex S.

description: Walked in atmosphere was very warm and cozy. The decor consisted of wine racks throughout the restaurant and bottles lined up the walls. I enjoyed penne with a tomato garlic sauce that was absolutely full of flavor. My dish came out really hot and remained hot throughout the entire time I ate. I enjoyed a glass of wine from the Francis Coppola diamond collection...it was so good I decided to purchase a bottle. The nice surprise was getting $10 off because I was taking it to go.
author: Vanessa J.

description:
Very beautiful and historic building.  I would recommend as a nice place to sit outside, have a glass of wine and people watch.  Sit on the Columbus side, as traffic seems not to be as noisy and busy as Kearney.  Not much variety with wines - all Coppola (prices were decent at least).  They only have 3 bottled beers (one was sapporo?)  

There was an area roped off for 'industry insiders' or whatever... somehow I doubt this place gets frequented by Hollywood's elite, but it adds a touch of drama.
author: Caroline C.

description: After a long afternoon of sight seeing on a freezing double decker bus, the warmth and atmosphere were welcome!  The food was very good, the staff very attentive!  I enjoyed immensely!  Caesar salad is fantastic, and my chicken scarpetta was delicious
author: Dawn A.

description: The layout the joint makes for an odd atmosphere. The bigger problem was the food. Cesar salad was good but the spaghetti and meatballs, not so much. It was a plate of undercooked pasta and tough to chew completely overlooked meatballs. A bit of a fail.
author: Scott M.

description:
I loved this place once upon a time , great pizzas and terrific bartenders at this small out of the way place.
However they recently let loose a  blonde manager who thinks she owns this place,,,,bad loud laughing and loud behavior is disgusting. Sad
author: Katherine N.

description: Came here for dinner last night. The food was excellent, very simple and tasty. It was a little weird walking in at 8:00 on a Wednesday night, seeing the place 2/3 full then being asked if I had a reservation, the hostess seemed a little snobby. But the rest of the meal was fantastic, including the bill!
author: Sam A.

description:
Swung by here last night for the Zoetrope All-Story magazine Latin America issue release party, but I've been meaning to go here for a long time, mainly because I pass by on the way to/from work every single day, and it always looks fun!  

I love the building itself, kind of like the Flatiron building in NYC, but with its own flair.  The oxidized copper trim is also really beautiful and classic.  It usually doesn't look too crowded but last night (7:30 pm on a Tuesday evening) it was hopping due to the event.  Nice looking, mature crowd and great wines and italian style nibbles.

Bonus points for the charming outdoor tables with lovely heatlamps - such a great amenity, especially here in San Francisco!
author: Jaimie M.

description: I arrived too early and was gently told to come back after they opened.  Came back and received really great service.  I was the only person in the section in which I was seated but the great thing was that I ordered the muffaletta (sp?) and a caesar salad and my waitress explained that the sandwich already came with a small salad and offered to see if they would change it to a caesar.  They did.  You're not in a tourist trap when they save you from spending $9 on a salad you don't need.  Or maybe you are and you just hit the waitress jackpot.  In any case, the sandwich was a lovely symphony of flavors, the bread in the basket was warm and nummy, and by the time I finished my meal I felt ready to spend the day on my feet in an unfamiliar city.
author: Carol P.

description:
Here is the deal.

The restaurant resides in a very historic beautiful building. The drinks and the food is priced well enough.

Quality:
It is nothing to brag about, but it's good. I would recommend. the pizza- they seem to have that down pretty well. As far anything else, you are taking a bit of a gamble in my opinion. 

Come here for the place itself and the pizza.

Tip:
They usually have a guitar player that starts around 6pm. Very cool.

You've just been yelped in.
author: Aaron A.

description: Stopped in today after lunch at House of Nan King for dessert and coffee.  It was 4pm and completely empty.  Dessert was awesome, but service was snooty and made us feel unwelcome.  I have been a waiter for ten years and work on Pier 39, and I send dozens of tourists to other restaurants throughout The City on a daily basis...  like Nan King...  I have told hundreds of people to go there...  I don't think I will be referring them to Zoetrope, and I am in no hurry to go back myself.  Jerk waiter (wearing glasses), even if I am just spending twenty dollars today, I eat out twice a week and could have brought you more business in the future, so you should be nice to all your clientele, instead of sizing them up when they walk in the door and decide they are not worth your time.
author: Joe S.

description:
Went here for lunch with the family, brothers + kids, this place is not kid friendly!!!!! or family friendly if I may say...
The hostess was rude and obnoxious.....we did not even get to sit down, when she asks " how many in the group?" and saw 2 strollers!!!! We got the cold shoulder, so offf we went out of the revolving door,,,,,,,,, Oh well, there are gazillion restaurants downtown......
author: Cara L.

description:
I've always been intrigued by the building. The architecture and materials used on the building are unique and antique.

The interior of the restaurant is small, but very cozy. The ambiance has a lively feel with old SF photos and black and white checkered floors. 

We had a large party of 11 and were able to be accommodated at the back of the restaurant. Our service was a delight. The wine was flowing and the Pizzas and pastas we all shared we plenty and delicious. 

It is a place I look forward to taking out of towners.
author: Dee C.

description:
Pizza is one of my favorite foods, and I had to try it from here since FFC has given his seal of approval, and he didn't steer me wrong.  Good NY style, filling, decently priced, and good service.  As a movie buff, the inside was a treasure trove of bits and pieces of Hollywood, FFC, and other interesting photos and posters.

The inside is a bit small, but that adds to the character.  With two glasses of wine and two desserts our meal was still very reasonable, and we had pizza to take home.  The waiters were very quick and friendly, the atmosphere was nice and laid back, and it's in a nice location close to the bay for a stroll afterwards.  My wife and I had a great time and will be back when we're in SF.
author: Matt W.

description: Been here a few times and I gotta say that I like this place. Service has always been good. Not the fastest service but compensates with friendliness. Food is pretty good, especially the spaghetti and meat balls. American size portions...can't finish them my self.
author: Teppo S.

description: This is a great place to go for some drinks and a bit of good food.  The building is gorgeous and does not feel american at all.  I drank the pinot noire which was smooth and reasonably priced at $8 a glass and got their cobb salad which is one of the best cobbs I've ever ordered.  Great place for before or after dinner drinks!
author: Laura P.

description:
i'm not quite sure why this place only averages 3 and a half stars. i went in for lunch by myself and sat at the bar. peter, the bartender, introduced himself and was delightful. i ordered some amazing pasta and a glass of great pinot. peter's cousin and a buddy came in and sat at the bar. i ate fantastic food and we talked about north beach, old and new. i finished, shook hands with all 3 of them and left feeling that i'd had the perfect north beach lunch. i'm wracking my brain trying to figure out where i could deduct stars and i'm coming up empty. the food and wine were fantastic, the service was flawless and friendly and i loved the professional yet breezy neighborhood vibe. it's not hip but there's too much 'hip' and not enough 'heart' in sf these days.  i will be back often!

6/20/07 update: wow. i went back today.  peter was there, the cousin was there, the friend was there. i ordered the same damn lunch and it was fantastic and peter's cousin shared some really good wine with me to boot. lawrence furlinghetti was walking out as i was walking in. still trying to figure out the 3 star average here.
author: Brian B.

description: A friend of mine worked here for 2 years, so I frequently visited the place and I still go back. The food is OK, nothing to write home about. The pizza is really good though. Not a big menu selection. The wine however is amazing. They do wine tasting flights for $13 & $16 and I love those. On a good day, you can actually see the man himself, Francis Ford Coppola dining at one of the tables. It's definitely a place you would want to show to your 'out of town' guests.
author: George M.

description: I was in San Francisco for two days visiting an old flame, and I ate here both of those days. The pizza is incredible. The service was impeccable. The staff seemed to walking around with the known smirk of bringing joy to the world. The second day that I was there I met a couple from Seattle, who frequent this establishment wherever they're in town. I had just come from a week long visit with a friend in Seattle. And of course the wine was fantastic. I still get a warm feeling when I see the label here on the east coast. Good eating.
author: George D.

description: I've been here a couple of times. Their pizzas were pretty good, but it isn't a place I'd rave about. There is also another one in Palo Alto.
author: Jeremy S.

description: I make a special trip here everytime I'm in town for a pizza. Soo good!
author: Meghan M.

description:
My friend & I had a lovely dinner last night here, and sat outside, under heat lamps, because the small inside was full.  Lovely all in all -- the waitress discouraged us from getting the pricier zin, saying that they were all comparable; the $33 bottle of Dry Creek was just what the doctor ordered.  The food was also excellent -- the puttanesca was perfect; my friend's broccoli rabe/Italian sausage/fontina dish was also pretty amazing (I snuck a bite, even though I'm vegan); portion size was perfect.

All in all, a totally cute place to add to my list of Cute Little Italian Restaurants To Which To Take A Date in North Beach.  I'll be back.
author: Nori H.

description:
My Irish-Catholic sister married a Russian Jew in a German town in North Georgia.

no joke.

this place is an Italian-ish place with French posters and a huge photo of some dude being doted on by 23 Cambodian or Vietnamese women.

which one is more hodge-podge, one wonders......

the food: meh - the service: meh - the place: random - the patrons (us) hungry and left satisfied because it was edible, but not really anything that stands out - especially in this city where people seem to sneeze and a new awesome resturant appears.
author: Barney B.

description: This is a cute little restaurant that our tour guide recommended in the Italian area of San Francisco.   Apparently, Francis Ford Coppola owns the building, and opened the Italian restaurant.  They have a Caesar salad there (and boast that it is where Caesar salad was first invented way-back-when).  The food was OK. We were hungry because we had just ran 13 miles earlier that day, so i definitely cleaned my plate:)
author: Sarah P.

description:
Cafe Zoetrope, formerly Cafe Neibaum Coppola is a neighborhood landmark. The building is owned my none other than Francis Ford Coppola. It's enough to go there, just to be near his greatness. The whole restaurant is plastered with pictures of Francis and film memorabilia, "American Graffiti", candid pictures of Francis. 

I had the pleasure of getting a tour of the building, down into the film room below with all the original 9 mm of favorites like "Apocalypse Now" and "The Godfather". You can taste all the Coppola reserve wines and of course his sparkling wine named after his daughter and director, Sophia. The food is Sicilian style, simple. 

I caught Francis outside one day smoking a cigar and having lunch with friends. How can you beat that? You gotta love the Italians..... 

Best double cappuccino in North Beach. Quite possibly in SF. Made with Illy Coffee. 

Great place to smoke a cigar outside, catch up on reading, and drink wine on a sunny afternoon.... 

"Simplicity is the ultimate sophistication." -Leonardo da Vinci
author: Sandy C.

description: Cool building. The food wasn't outstanding as I had expected. The place is basically a shrine to pay homage to Mr. Coppola.
author: J D.

description:
It just doesn't add up if the only 5-star reviews are from people with only one review ever written. Is that you Francis Ford?

So I finally ate there, & it was just not that good. If it's after 5 pm, go to TOMMASO'S!

FOOD:~prosciutto arugula pizza wasn't that good. it's the crust..it's dry & bland. & the ingredients were mediocre.

~the cheese/salumi platter was great though! the mozzarella di bufala was yummy & fresh-tasting, all the cheese were great, & the salumi was acceptable.

DECOR: beautiful. i like!

SERVICE: nice. the guy tried to get me passes for the coppola winery in napa (since it's like $35 just to go inside) but they were out. he also gave me a parking hookup ;)

OVERALL: i'd go to stare @ francis ford if he's in there...before i eat @ tommaso's.
author: miss b.

description:
After waking up at the Palomar Hotel, then playing all day at Fort Funston, I found myself at this restaurant in the late afternoon.  We sat at the outside tables and they were nice about letting me & my labrador hang out.

Great bread and pizza & Pasta.
author: Roach D.

description:
I've been to Cafe Niebaum-Coppola/Zoetrope about three times, always for lunch.  I had a great time every time.  It seems every time I've gone, there's been nobody there (on a weekday, but still...), which is puzzling.

It's a bit expensive for basic Italian, but the food is good.  The wine is great.  The decor is stunning.

A nice place to go when you want to dip into nostalgic-type San Francisco.
author: Linda B.

description:
Go for the pizza and caesar salad. If you're lucky,  grab a stool by the bar and chat it up with Peter. His head is full of a wealth of North Beach trivia and he is a heck of a nice man to boot!  He's not shy about making a few recommendations if you ask - anything from an entree to what you pour in that wine glass sitting in front of you. 
And don't you LOVE those rose-colored glasses. Cool surroundings even when FFC isn't in town for a viewing. But always keep your eyes open...you never know WHO might drop by.....
author: Trish D.

description: Stopped in for lunch. Right around corner from Hilton Hotel. Excellent service. Cool building and priced right!  Lunch special menu had a nice variety. Try the spinach and ricotta gnocchi with a tomato cream sauce!  Excellent.
author: Kate K.

description: The prices were reasonable and the food was tasty!  We ordered the gnocchi and the Pizza Sofia, both of which were delicious.   The service was great, and it's a nice atmosphere.  The food wasn't out-of-this-world good, but I would probably go again!
author: Tamiko T.

description:
What potential in this great location. 
I was drawn in by this unique triangle cafe, and thought what a great place to chill and enjoy a little early dinner. I walked in, asked if I could sit outside, 3 waiters said yes, and one brought me a menu within a minute.
Some average fare/small selection to choose from, but again, great location. I waited for over 10 minutes, watched the other 2 small parties eat, and gestured for someone to take my order. There were about 5 staff people "working" the floor.
No one ever came..... 
Disappointing, but good thing Chinatown and many other choices are  within walking distance.
author: Cheryl H.

description: Just stopped in for a glass of wine. Perfect location to just sit and watch everyone walk by. One of the most unique buildings around. Very cool, cozy inside. Great wine from Coppola vineyards, as it's owned by FFC.
author: Jeff P.

description: Been here before, and it was just as good as last time. Cool building off Columbus boarder China Town and North Beach. Atmosphere is great, good place to people watch and inside is quite. The food is well made ad good. Reasonable prices. I love the Cesar Salad, so far they have the best Caesar Salad i have tasted. The wines of course are great . By the bottle or glass. Service was excellent. They know about the dishes and of course about the wine. Walking distance to all the other eateries and clubs. Check it out.
author: Susie S.

description:
Rustic Italian pizzas and pastas in the awesome Sentinel building.  The food is way more hearty and homemade tasting than the surrounding North Beach restaurants and the Coppola wines are all good (and many are cheap).  I've never seen it crowded and the staff always seem genuinely happy to have us walk through the doors making this a good place to stop in for quick, filling meals.  

I'm still a little confused about the name though...I think this place is now called Caf Zoetrope while the one in Palo Alto is Cafe Niebaum-Coppola?

Update:  Went back again last night and had wine and desserts outside on an odd warm evening in late October.  Service was nice if inexperienced, but the wine and view were awesome.
author: Cory G.

description:
We decided to check out this place because some friends that are writers were visiting.  The building is my favorite in San Francisco.  The food was good and reasonably priced. We had a large antipasto plate with fresh mozzarella, olives, hams, eggplant and cheeses.  I ordered the spaghetti and meatballs, the meatballs were large and tasty.  Entrees and pizza were between $12-$15.  My husband had a glass of the Sophia Rose wine and I was surprised what a small amount of wine was served in such a huge glass for $8.  I would like to try it out for lunch sometime and sit outside.  Service was friendly.  
I would not recommend it for a large group.
author: Molly B.

description:
A condensed review for those short of patience:

The pizza here is super good.  If one were to optimize the experience of Neopolitan pizza, one should order it with heirloom tomatoes.  Then it is simply divine!  The staff has always been super nice and professional.  It's perfect for taking the out of towners who deserve better than fisherman's wharf.
author: Ricky R.

description:
What can I say? Lovely from the outside, lovely on the inside, but for what you pay, the food is "blah."

My lady and I were wandering around looking for a "cute little Italian place" for dinner. We stumbled upon Cafe Zoetrope and decided to give it a try. The service was a bit slow to start with and non-existent towards the end of our meal. After perusing the wine list, I quickly realized it was a Coppolla restaurant - which was fine by me because I normally enjoy Coppolla's wines.

We ordered an appetizer (a cheese and meat plate) and when it came, the waiter just dropped it off and left. Now, normally, when I order some sort of sampler appetizer item (especially meat and cheese plates,) the server gives you a little detail on what he's laid in front of you. For example: "This is a Chevre with herbs and blah blah from Oregon, this is a prosciutto di parma from blah blah and is one of my personal favorites...." etc etc. You get the picture.

We then followed up with entrees. She had the classic: two softball-sized meatballs and spaghetti and I had the Pizza Sofia (arugula and prosciutto pizza.) Not bad, but definitely not amazing (to their defense, how "amazing" can you get with spaghetti and meatballs and a pizza?)

I would say, if you want some tasty wine and just a little snack to nibble on with friends and family and don't mind being ignored and want to sit for hours-on-end chit chatting, then come here. It would be perfect. But, if you're looking for a quiet and intimate dinner experience with excellent service and great food -- look elsewhere.
author: Brent S.

description: I work in the building so I might be a little bias but I love Cafe Zoetrope. The food is excellent and the service is outstanding. They have a great selection of wine- i would reccomend the Coppola tasting if its your first time. This place feels like a little family. Everyone knows one another. The bartender Peter is great... super nice and friendly and shared some awesome facts about San Francisco with me (hes been here his whole life). The outside eating is nice because the heated lamps. I like that it is away from the main strip of North Beach. The casear salad is awesome and the dressing is an original recipe from years and years ago. I would reccommend this place for dinner or just to sip good wine and read outside.
author: Nina Q.

description: Amazing restaurant. To start, the building itself and the architecture is so cool. Pictures and paintings inside the restaurant make it seem like you are in Italy. The inside of the restaurant is a little small and cramped, but you cant beat sitting at the outside tables on a sunny day. Food is great! Had a delicious butternut squash soup which was to die for. Shared a pizza with my Dad and had more than enough left over. They also give you a complementary bread basket and you can get butter, or olive oil and basalmic vinegar. The wine choices are great, my personal favorite is the Sophia (a pink, sparkly wine). Service was good, staff was very nice and attentive. My water glass was always full and the waiters were on top of it. The pricing of the items on the menu were very reasonable considering it is in SF and in a busy part of town. I would definitely recommend this restuarant to anyone!
author: Margaret C.

description: Stopped here to share a pizza as a snack. They offer many wines by the glass and several flexible options for flights of 3 wines -which is a nice touch. Memorabilia and photos from Francis Ford Coppola on the walls. Mr Coppola even made an appearance.
author: Sharon M.

description:
Ya know, I really enjoyed my dinner here.  Overall, this place is solid.  Good food, good service, good location, good ambiance.  It's like the 3rd bowl of porridge that Goldilocks tried - not too hot, not too cold, not too big, not too small.  

I had the penne arrabiata, which was quite good, fresh and the pasta was cooked perfectly.  This isn't the type of Italian place where they put cheese on everything, which is always a hint of quality if you ask me.  The cowboy got a panini, which he says was good and looked pretty delicious to me.  Portions were a perfect size, and the price was good too.  A pitcher of table wine is $15, and it's pretty dang good.  Crushed red pepper (Coppola's own brand of course) comes on every table as does bread and olive oil / balsamic.  The service was excellent and the outdoor sidewalk seating is surprisingly quiet.

Coppola has done a great job on making Zoetrope as close to European sidewalk dining as you can get.  He could have gone all snobby on this one, but he didn't, and it turned out great.
author: Katherine K.

description:
Enjoyable like your 19th trip to disneyland.  

Apocalypse Now was pretty good though.
author: Patrick A.

description:
I went here tonight with a friend for a casual dinner after a couple hours at the spa. We walked in only to be told by the greeter that there were no tables available and we would have to wait 20 minutes. I saw some empty seats that the bar, but it was only after I suggested it that she offered it. 

Our bartender was super cool, but the rest of the service seemed a little disorganized. I almost ordered a glass of Torrontes wine (from Argentina), but the bartender was nice enough to allow me to taste it first, after which I decided I didn't care for it and went for the crisp Sofia Blanc de Blancs instead. For food, my friend and I split the Caesar salad, which they were cool enough to split before bringing it to the bar. The Caesar salad was good, which just the right amount of anchovies for a nice flavor. We ordered a pizza with prosciutto, salami, fresh mozzarella, blue cheese, reggiano, marinated peppers, and olives. However, the interesting thing was the toppings all arrived to the side along with the plain flat bread pizza, and therefore we had to work to construct each slice with these ingredients and of course, nothing stayed on the slice and everything fell off, making it a messy experience. It also didn't help that we weren't given a individual plates for the pizzas meaning that I had to try to eat this over my salad bowl. Regardless, the pizza was pretty yummy, making all the effort sort of worthwhile.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Coppola makes some great films, but he does not get the Oscar for food. Some friends took us there a year ago, and the pasta was average.  Well, chewy, undercooked. A year later, the pasta was average, chewy, undercooked. The waiter said the bread was homemade, but never bothered to give us plates to dip bread in olive oil. Next time we want the Coppola experience, we'll stay home and rent The Godfather and order a pizza in.
author: Yvo R.

description:
My mouth is watering for the food... 

Erik and I have walked by here, but never stopped to eat because it looked expensive. 

One day we did stop in and I was pleasantly surprised! 

The food was Delicious! I forgot what I ordered, but it was pasta and it was reasonable! (Maybe because my expectations were low in the first place. It's always nice to have low expectations and then for them to be exceeded). 

Service - excellent! The waitress was really nice. She gave us a little history of the name change and was knowledgeable with the wine. It was moderately busy. I am surprised more people don't eat here. 

Decor: Tastefully decorated. Wine bottles up along the walls, nice windows looking out to the street, cute table and chairs outside (with heating lamps). 

All in all, it was a memorable dinner. Yummy food, excellent company and conversation, and personable/friendly wait staff. 

Also, I disagree with some of the other reviews about being a tourist trap - I didn't see any.
author: Cynthia C.

description: We had some drinks here. Our negroni was good. The staffs were friendly. Too bad we were already full when we came here, I would love to try their food.
author: Lora M.

description: Didn't eat, only stopped in for a glass of wine. Great atmosphere, the bartender was very personable and engaging and I love the building. Will keep on my list for future visits.
author: Heathet B.

description: I give it 2 1/2 stars for the historic building and for the food being decent. The service was lacking and this is the biggest cause for a lackluster review. I felt like a burden to them at times, and all I did was order and eat. I'm as low maintenance as they come. I don't know how this place stays open going forward with all the competition unless they fix their service problems.
author: Mike W.

description: Went a second time and tried their pizza.  Got the basic cheese.  I liked the style a lot and it was a nice sized portion.  $14.  I was expecting a small personal serving but I think it's more meant for 2 as a shared appetizer with your drinks.  This place on a whole is a little pricey for my tastes but it's old school classiness is refreshing and I really like the fact that it's in a sort of neutral territory between 'hoods that makes it feel more relaxing for some reason.
author: Marc S.

description:
Cafe Zoetrope:

What won me over was the decor in this place.  For some reason, I was just fascinated and thought it was so interesting.  Since I was stuck on East Coast time, my friend and I had lunch (or maybe it was dinner) at 3 so it was dead quiet.  Being anti-cheese, I loved the cheese-less basil and garlic pizza and my friend enjoyed the pasta.  Reasonable prices.  Excellent service.
author: Bryanne R.

description: This place is a small and  quant upscale cafe that I highly recommend.  Great Carbonara. The Tiramisu is the best I have ever had! Loved our waiter, David. We will definitely go back very soon! :)
author: Chari K.

description:
A little pretentious and pricey but you have to expect that at a restaurant owned by a celebrity.  You're paying for the opportunity to see FFC dine with George Lucas (as we did last night).  It's a fairly small restaurant, which gives it a cozy, homey feel.  The restaurant is also designed to be a showcase for FFC's wines, which were surprisingly good.

But at the same time, the food is great!  The house specialty is a beef-pork blend meatball served with spaghetti (naturally) and it was easily the best version I've ever had.  Two fist-sized meatballs over a well-balanced and tasty tomato-basil sauce looked rather skimpy at first but was satisfying nonetheless.

I definitely have to go back and try the pizza next time.
author: Russ H.

description: Beautiful building, delicious wine, and tasty pizza.  I lingered here on a Saturday afternoon with a glass of red and a good book, but I had to keep putting the book down to watch the neighborhood (Financial District meets North Beach) and to look at everything in the cafe (the inner world of the cafe tells the story of Francis Ford Coppola).  The only downside to this place is that if more tables fill up than are empty (which is bound to happen with the theme of the place) then the one waiter on staff is taxed out.  Wonderful experience, though.
author: Jo S.

description:
Excellent & "woody" atmosphere, classic photos of FFC with his various film friends & past film crews abound and the food's not too bad either.

Some "authentic" Italian/Sicilian dishes and tasty desserts at a not too expensive price really make it worth it.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
This place is one of my north beach standbys.  The best food in the neighborhood that isn't accompanied by a rude 'tood.

The fare is generally lighter than most of the competition.  Standouts in this vein are the Pizza Sofia, penne alla tonno, and the penne funghi.  On the heavier side check out the calzone, rigatone with sausage, and spaghetti alla carbonara.  And don't miss the garlicky braised spinach!
author: Phill W.

description: Returned in January. Antipasto was incredible, spaghetti and meatballs were very good. Pizza, however, was actually pretty bad. Not sure what the problem is, this place has a problem with consistency. Sometimes its excellent, other times not. Last spring the pizza was awesome, this time not so much. For now this remains my back-up place for when the wait at Tony's is too long, but until they resolve consistency problems will not be a first choice.
author: Eric R.

description: This place was awesome!  i love the cocktails and the decor!  and both the service and food were surprisingly great!  It was a rainy friday night and we had a party of 7!!! and they accommodated us quickly for a long dinner!!!  all the pizzas and pastas dishes are amazing, not to mention they have a great selection of wine!
author: Shirley Z.

description: The best place to go for Italian in North Beach if you want Italian but don't realllly want to deal with North Beach. It can even be fabulously inexpensive, and you know, dude, it just feels special inside.
author: Shannon V.

description: Cool looking building with great memorabliia hanging on the walls but mediocre food that is way overpriced. You are obviously paying for the Coppolla name. Good spot to bring a group of friends for pizza and drinks but expect to be judged by the snobby bartender and host/waiter guy the moment you walk in. They are dressed up in a shirt and tie and if you walk in there not looking like you are rich they will give you shitty service and turn their noses up at you.
author: Dusty N.

description: We rented out the entire restaurant for a Graduation Party from Medical School.The Manager Lidia Valledor was fantastic-very professional and knowledgeable .Our guests were treated to a wonderful evening of really delicious food and great wines.The wait staff were exceptional and were anxious to take care of all our needs.Lidia also recommended an amazing photographer who turned out to be exactly what we wanted. I would definitely recommend Cafe Zoetrope for your special event they will not disappoint
author: Katie W.

description: Bringing friends in on a Saturday night from Sydney, I was excited to return to Zoetrope after having a great lunch there a year earlier . This time was a disappointment . First after calling to say we were going to be 15 minutes late due to traffic the hostess said to please hurry because of a very booked night ( it was a Saturday night at 7:30) ,When we arrived there was only one couple at a table in an empty restaurant . The service was ok if not a bit rushed ( in an empty restaurant ? ) .The food was a big disappointment. My puttanesca had a slight metallic taste to in after a lack luster salad, my friend had the carbonara ,a soggy mess .the spaghetti and meatballs were declared good by our 14 year old guest ,no one else commented on their meal.Over all  the the ambience and the fantastic building the restaurant is in was better than the food .Don't expect to see the GODFATHER to be eating there.....
author: Glenn M.

description:
I've heard this place is always empty - and our visit on a Tuesday night proved that rumor correct.  It was, however, perfect for a group of 13 - attentive staff, but not over chatty, the meals/desserts/wine came quickly, and the place wasn't loud and crowded, so our group could chat without competing with other customers.  

I thought the ambiance and service was great.  I like Francis Cappola wine, which is a majority (if not all) they serve.  

The food, meh, I could have made myself at home - not bad, but not super impressive for a date, etc.  The appetizers - cheese and meet tray - were nice, but the pasta wasn't homemade or spectacular.

Good for company-funded group dinners in my opinion, not dates.
author: Amber M.

description:
Went here for a romantic Valentines Day lunch and was pleasantly surprised. 

The building is a wonderful example of the the 1900's Flatiron style architecture. With the interior of the cafe tastefully decorated with numerous photo's of Francis Ford Copella's (FFC) movie making career (he owns the building/cafe).

The service was great to begin with (when the restaurant was pretty empty) but tailed off to slightly inattentive as things picked up. None the less overall it was good.

The food was delicious, home style, Italian fare. The gourmet pizzas looked tasty and definitely not-run-of-the-mill. The pasta was fresh and aldente - and so it should be, they make all their own pasta fresh daily on the premises.

Extensive wine selection - albeit weighted heavily towards FFC's private label.

Overall - a great dining experience. Would definitely recommend it for a romantic dinner, or a (semi) casual lunch.
author: Vortex X.

description:
Great Italian comfort food .  The restaurant itself is small which helps add to the atmosphere. Some fantastic pictures on the wall of Francis Ford Coppola and friends.  The menu itself is nice and simple and there were also specials available.  

We kicked things off by sampling a few different wines.  I personally was a fan of the Reserve Syrah, 2008.  

We started with the Insalta Verde, which was very simple and dressed very well.  For the main course we had the Spaghetti and Meatballs and the Bumbola ai Broccoli e Salsiccia.  The meatballs were a blend of beef, veal and pork and very flavorful.  The Bumbola was outstanding and I would highly recommend this to anyone, perfectly seasoned.  Very filling portions, but not overwhelming.  For dessert we had the panna cotta which was delicious.  

The staff was great and very attentive.  The water glass was never empty.  We had a great experience here, definitely recommend this restaurant, we plan to return.
author: Michael S.

description: I had been to the sound editing studio in the basement below this space a bunch of times for work, tempted by the smells wafting in from the kitchen, but had never tried the food here until last night. It did not disappoint! We got a simple radicchio salad and a couple of pasta dishes, and everything was delicious. The service was friendly, flirtatious, and well-paced - slow enough to feel leisurely, but fast enough that no one got annoyed. I'd definitely return to try the pizzas!
author: lindsay m.

description: I just went  to Cafe Zoetrope, for the first time.  I was excellent!  Great food, great atmosphere, and excellent service!  I was impressed.
author: Moon Star X.

description: Food was extremely average, ordered the same chicken meal as an older gentleman sitting nearby, his came well presented on a steaming hot plate. Mine- a soupy plate of poorly balanced flavours with under seasoned chicken and overdone vegetables. Poor show.
author: Cameron A.

description: Loved this place nice comfortable, friendly neighborhood bistro.  Was in town on business and dining alone couldn't have been more comfortable.  food was good and portions generous. Thanks for the nice evening.
author: Bonnie B.

description: The wait staff and service was terrible. I waited for over 20 minutes in did not get my drink. They took our orders, not writing anything down and proceed to serve food we did not even order. I would not recommend to anyone.
author: Jay R.

description:
As I sat down in this charming cafe-restaurant atmosphere, I was immediately transported to a world other than the busy streets of San Francisco. Though, I might normally find Frank Sinatra playing a bit cliche, it was comforting in this cozy, and oddly shaped restaurant. Bottles of wine lined the walls, and the mosaic floor was unique without trying too hard. The tables are a tight squeeze, and perhaps uncomfortable if I were there at night, with parties on either side of me.
 My server seemed distracted by the guy yelling at him from the kitchen, and was walking around as I attempted to give him my order, I simply waited for him to be still before I continued. The voice coming from the downstairs area, where the kitchen was, did not bother me, in fact it was charming in its own stereotypical "loud Italian" way. However, what did bother me, was the food.
 The salad was fine, the ingredients were fresh, and I enjoyed it with a few pieces of bread in olive oil. My entree was a different story. The sauce was bland, the linguine were not cooked completely and, the clams, other than drowning in white wine, were not salvation for this poorly executed dish.
 As I finished my meal, I overheard a conversation between three men (whom I like to think of as Gino, Carlo, and Michael) at the bar, which is small, but impressive in its variety of liqueurs. Their conversation made me smile, I felt like I was really in Italian town, and I wondered if this was a real conversation happening at this very moment. Could I be the lucky eavesdropper who overheard these real life Dons talking about "The Family"? Or was this an act they put on for all their customers? All I needed to hear next was "Go to the Mattresses", and my lunch at Zoetrope would have been redeemed. Unfortunately that did not happen. The best part of my visit to Francis Ford Coppola's San Francisco location was music and the people, sadly not having anything to do with the food.
 Though nothing blew me away food wise, I would gladly return to this cozy hideout, for a casual afternoon lunch. I would not, however, take anyone I was trying to impress, like a client for work, or a first or second date.
author: Kierke P.

description: This place was just sad and I don't imagine it will be around much longer. Maybe they are under new management now? It's a bummer that this cafe/restaurant has to occupy the base of the historical Sentinel Building. The feeling when my girlfriend and I walked in was immediately off putting (should have taken this as a sign) but we decided to get an espresso anyway (I would not recommend getting food here). They are located in a nice area and we wanted to sit outside to enjoy the sunshine. The espresso looked/tasted like watered down coffee and had no crema. We asked them to remake it but the second attempt was even worse than the first. The servers obviously had not been trained in how to use the machine or just didn't care to use the machine the proper way when pulling an espresso shot. When the barista was tamping down the ground coffee I watched carefully and I don't think I've ever seen anyone apply such little pressure or put in so little effort when doing such a simple task. We ended up just leaving our drinks outside on the table and headed to Bask across the street which was a much more pleasant experience. We used to pass American Zoetrope all the time when we would go to this area remarking how cute it was and how we should stop by sometime. Well now we know. I never really write reviews but this was such a bad experience I felt compelled to save people wasted time and money on this one.
author: Scott M.

description: Neat building, great funky decor, friendly staff, and then to top it all off, excellent pizza!
author: John P.

description:
"when an hour isn't just an hour - but A LITTLE BIT OF ETERNITY dropped in your hands - and who knows what to do. with it?" 

so says Blanche DuBois, Tennesseee Williams' mad diva of desire as she honeys up a beautiful young man in the late afternoon...that sweet after lunch before dinner time when really you shouldn't be hungry and yet the pangs of desire softly claw.

If you're lucky, at that moment, you pass by a triangle of architectural wonder shaped like a bronzed piece of pie, stroll in, and sit on a soft round bench behind a marble table and peruse a menu filled with both light and hearty fare. 
We ordered:
 insalata finnochio that was heavenly light lemoned fennel with greens
       sauteed spinaci like emeralds oiled for love
                and broccoli rabe. eat your vitamin filled fiber as if it were the ice cream of immortality. THAT simply good.

Service was pleasant, but slooooow and required prompting at almost every turn from a second request for water to a correction to an overheard "they're ready for the check" before we had been shown the dessert menu or had a chance to ask for espresso. The bussers appeared to be so deep in conversation with each other and enraptured with polishing glasses that they couldn't be bothered by our existence, much less our needs. I have to say, I saw them ignore our waiter's requests for their assistance with an equal level of complete dismissal.

The food was very fresh and savory, simply prepared with just the perfect amount of olive oil and lemon; presentation was a basic white plated here it is.  Seemed just right for the bistro ambiance and the straightforward dishes. Prices were reasonable for freshly prepared tasty Italian fare in a landmark North Beach cafe. 

I would add that when my macchiato appeared it was dry foam-as-a-filter, not-a-puddle perfection exactly as ordered and as ninety percent of the valencia barristas cannot *ahem Rituals* produce. That added a Star from three to four right there. I am not shouting bravissimo, but I am smiling with inner abandon. maybe better this joy held back a little.

So if you have a leisurely afternoon to indulge your idle hunger, wander in. Be prepared to wait on the waiters and/or to attempt to interrupt their mid-day reverie. Once you do, they will smile and deliver as you wish. A small price for tidbits of immortality.
author: Squinka C.

description:
I was so disappointed by this place.  I came on Sunday 5/20, Bay to Breakers day, at 2pm.  There were 3 tables filled.  When I entered, I was asked if I wanted to sit at the bar, and I said no, I was here for lunch and preferred a table.  No problem, I was seated at a table, and sat there for the next 10 minutes waiting for someone to bring me a menu, or water, or acknowledge that I was there.  Never happened.  So I got up and searched someone out for a menu.  A few minutes later, I had a few questions for the server, which he answered.  When asked if he would recommend the short ribs, he said they were very fatty-about 50% fat-and gave me the impression that no, he would not recommend the ribs.  I asked about the special pasta of the day and he said it was in a very rich sauce, very heavy, and also gave me the impression he would not recommend it.  OK, so I asked about the special grilled chicken salad and the muffaletta.  He said both were good so that's what I ordered.

I waited over 20 minutes for the salad.  I wasn't in a hurry, so that's OK, but given how slow the restaurant was, it seemed odd.  The people next to me, who came in after me and ordered after me, were already done with their pizza and I was still waiting to be served anything.  Well, hopefully the wait would be worthwhile.  It wasn't.  The chicken was cut into small greatly over-cooked pieces which had no flavor except dried out chicken.  And very skimpy on the amount.  There were also "caramelized onions" which were simply burned onions.  So $11 for a salad with maybe 1 ounce of dried out chicken, and a few pieces of burned onion.  Great.

The muffaletta ($18) comes in quarter, half and whole sizes.  The whole is supposed to be $18, but  they charged me $20 for it, since I asked for it "to go".  I've never paid higher prices for a to order, but OK.  Well, that muffaletta was one bad sandwich.  A classic muffaletta (which this is supposed to be) comes on a round loaf of bread, with at least 1 1/4 pounds of meat and cheeses, and an olive spread.  The bread was good and true to a muffaletta, but the amount of meats and cheeses--maybe 1/2 pound for this large loaf, were so skimpy and so tasteless.  And the olive spread (in this case mushrooms spread) was also so skimpy that depending upon which quarter of the sandwich you ate, you may not have gotten any of the spread.

I am totally amazed that people gave this place good reviews.  Maybe I ordered the wrong items, but that does not excuse the poor service.  There are so many good places to eat in North Beach,I can only assume people come here for the FFC connection-so if you want poor over priced food with terrible service but some pictures of FFC, this is the place.

As I was leaving, the people next to me were leaving too, and I asked how their pizza was; they said they didn't even bother finishing it, it was so bad.
author: Dan L.

description: very nice ambience, amazing wine selection, food is authentic Italian but not mind blowing, very solid, great date place in SF
author: Shane P.

description: Really surprised at how reasonable the prices are at this place. It's one of the few places I've been to eat where I didn't feel they overcharged for what you got. The drinks are excellent and not overpriced either. Great service and of course the place has a great atmosphere. I'll be back.
author: Corey V.

description: This combination wine bar, cafe, and retail store is located in the historic Sentinel Building, which offers a wonderful contrast to the Transamerica building when the two are captured, seemingly side-by-side, on film. The interior is a bit cramped, but there's also alfresco dining if you don't mind the steady flow of traffic coming at you from three different directions. Since both the building and bistro are owned by Francis Ford Coppola, whose American Zoetrope offices are situated above, the renowned director is often on the premises. The menu includes family recipes for mostly northern Italian favorites. One exception is the muffaletta - the classic New Orleans sandwich of mozzarella, ham, mortadella, and salami with an olive topping - a whole one of which easily can feed a family of four. Among the pasta options is an outstanding Penne all' Arrabbiata, with a spicy sauce comprised of tomatoes, olives, capers, and garlic. I haven't tried any of the wide array of pizzas, but the Calzone Ripieno, stuffed with tomatoes, mozzarella, salami, ham, mushroom, and artichokes, is excellent and large enough for two to share. Not surprisingly, the spotlight is on wines from Niebaum-Coppola in the Napa Valley. Quite honestly, I'm perplexed by the generally mediocre views, as I have found the reasonably-priced food to be consistently good and the service always pleasant.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
sitting at the outside tables sipping on a glass of pinot takes me back to the places in nyc minus the car honking and city grime.

i like that they make their caesar salad with real egg yolks.  the thin crust pizzas are tasty fare though i have yet to try out the pasta.

so bring along a pair of shades, a good girlfriend to catch up wiith and maybe a dose of patience since the service is spotty.
author: Anh V.

description: I love Apocalypse Now, pizza, and decent vino, but that's not the draw here.  If you want some laughs, show up with a bunch of 20-something chicks.   Within moments, watch a bevy of  mid-iife crisis vultures spin their  yarns of student loan payments, trips to Tuscany, and cunnilingus.  Howls.
author: Nick D.

description: Overall an ok experience - service was really all over the place but at least friendly. They cooked the meatballs within an inch of their life, they were so difficult to even cut into. Pizzas were great.
author: Champagne Girl S.

description: Went back to the Cafe the other day....still very good.  Took some friends the other day...they were very pleasantly surprised by the delicious pizza. They loved the whole SF ambience and cafe seen...Great place...
author: Marilyn W.

description: I'm shocked it's not more popular. One of the most gorgeous buildings in the city. Interesting and unique photos inside and damn good food. Any Coppola fans must attend.
author: Eric K.

description: It just seems like a tourist trap. Yeah, Im a fan of the movies but it is kind of like who cares if it is owned by Francis Ford Coppola. They couldnt even make me a decent martini.  They were not overly friendly or anything either. It has an okay central location. In fact it seems that it is in the middle of the road-maximum exposure. The crowd was a mixture of jaded film buffs and people from the mid west.
author: Jason W.

description: It's in one of my favorite buildings in the City but I have to say that it's just an okay place to go eat. The staff is pretty attentive and the memoribilia is pretty impressive. It's just one of the many options that one can go to in the North Beach area.
author: janet j.

description: Two stars simply for the location, good place to check out the street scene of the neighborhood on the edge of both North Beach and Chinatown.  You're paying though for the name of it all, not really for anything of super high quality.  Sometimes you gotta take your mom here I suppose but otherwise, pass this one by.
author: Rob M.

description: I love this place, from the bread to wine it is top notch. I'm picky about real Italian food this place is well over looked by most locals and tourist. Bonus on certain nights Francis wil be dining right next to you like the other night for us. Went to his winery because of this place and food their is great too. Have fun evening and the staff is GREAT. Love the building, food and staff A+++++
author: Mia M.

description: I've never sat inside here. Seems nice. Been through on the way to the downstairs bathrooms. Outside is nice. Service is hit or miss -- sometimes snooty, sometimes friendly. I liked their old spin the dial appetizer menu (which is gone) but I still like their little pizzas. Really good spaghetti and meatballs. And a nice place to relax outside with dogs while they bask in the hot sun.
author: Margie L.

description: My friend and I went here for a late lunch.  A little on the expensive side, they only have one menu, no lunch menu.  We both had pizza for $13.50 (I had sausage/mushroom she had sort of a fold over crazy filled calzone thing) but they were so big we were able to eat it for dinner too.  I recommend sharing one, then it's only 1/2 the price!  Pizza was good, but probably wouldn't go back, the menu doesn't have enough variety.
author: Sarah M.

description: Love Francis Ford and all,but I think basically this winery/eatery is nothing but HYPE. Ive been there about 5 times, and every time my eating experience has been unenjoyable.
author: Lauren V.

description: I was at the end of my recent vacation in San Francisco, tooling around North Beach, my husband and I hit up Cafe Zoetrope for a quick bite.  We enjoyed a table outside on Kearny and enjoyed people watching while we ate pizza and drank iced tea.  We were outta there on time and on budget.
author: Amanda J.

description: Go for the atmosphere.  It's a very unique building with cute little tables and lots of windows.  The outdoor seating is lovely if the weather is nice.  The pizza was delicious and the caesar salad is a must have.  Lots of wine choices and a table roped off in case Francis Ford Coppola ever stops in (which he sometimes does).  A little pricey with slow service, but definitely worth it.
author: Brig M.

description: I went here for a glass of wine on a sunny afternoon, enjoying a chat with this place's friendly patrons. However the claret was served at room temperature, which was somewhere like 80 degrees that day. Ladies and gentlemen, red wine is often best served at room temperature indeed, but that is French countryside room temperature on an average day of the year. And that is more like 63 degrees.
author: Rene V.

description: The simplicity of this restaurant, the service/attitude, the food & wine make it the perfect combination. It was a quiet night in the restaurant so the food came out very quickly, great specials and they make a great Cesar salad. It's nice to have some of the N/C wines that are not available at retail without having to go to the winery.
author: Whitney P.

description: I loved this restaurant! Definitely a cool atmosphere inside. The mojito was really tasty. The food was super good! I split a pizza and a caesar salad, which was plenty of food. The staff was really friendly and accommodating. I definitely want to try more of the wines next time I come, which will hopefully be soon!
author: Sonya D.

description: What more can I say? I come here at least once a week. Not for the pretty, funny, witty wait staff. I come here for the ambiance, service, and of course... the food. When I am dining by myself, this is my no.1 place I think of. Beautiful building throughout and damn good everything else. I get a bowl of spagetti with meat balls and wash it down with a glass of claret. The zabanyoni with fruit it just the thing if there is still room in your belly. When I want a change I order the antipasti platter instead of the meat ball with spagetti. The cheese is heaven and the eggplant spread (I normally hate eggplant!) is great with the bread brought to your table. All in all, a very high rating! Enjoy!
author: Charise B.

description: Cafe Zoetrope is where you go for authentic Italian food and hospitality. I've been here at least 20 times during my San Francisco years, and I have always had a wonderful time. They serve the best Spaghetti Carbonara outside of Italy. It's made with ground black pepper, Guanciale (Italian Speck) and Pecorino Romano (Italian cheese). Or try the Pizza Sofia with prosciutto, arugula, and parmigiano. They also have great salads, especially the Radicchio Treviso with orange and balsamic dressing. I miss this place so much.
author: Sandra R.

description: The cafe is just what it is, but in my opinion the building is one of the most magically beautiful structures in San Francisco
author: Kelly S.

description: We went for lunch a couple of days ago, and I'd definitely go back! Cafe Zoetrope is charming and has a very European feel (including Italian wait staff!). The space is small but comfy, and the food was very good. I loved the mufalatti special (gnocchi stuffed with spinach & ricotta, in a tomato sauce with a touch of cream). The pizza was also yummy. I'm looking forward to trying more on my next visit!
author: Mina M.

description: Fantastic red wine selection and comfortable booth seating. Good cheese appetizer platter with olive spread too. Awesome people watching on Kearny or Colombus from any table.
author: Julie C.

description: I always stare at that beautiful green building but never thought to eat at the cafe, I was pleasantly surprised when I finally did.  I thought the pizza was extremely good and light, totally guilt free.  It's also an interesting place b/c of the different photos and writings hung on the walls.
author: Debbie Y.

description: My wife and I stopped in for a glass of wine after visiting the Coit Tower and before dinner at the Boulevard. We have always wanted to stop, but never got around to it. Next time we stay for dinner.
author: Terry G.

description: Nice little cafe/bistro in a cool building. Too bad the food doesn't measure up at all.
author: Ossama A.

description: I was really hurting for options here with the menu, but the food was traditional.  I had the spinach which was very simple and adequate.  I don't remember what the pizza was called but it was one that you could build up yourself from a tray of ingredients.  The uniqueness of that experience and the outdoor seating in the sun are my main recommendations.
author: CAKE E.

description: The food is good, though it might not the best place in North Beach. It's an atmosphere place. The building is of course stunningly photogenic, just being there is a treat in itself, for me anyway...I'm a sucker for these places that are supposed to be all Eurochic and stuff. I only ate there once, on a weeknight when it was quieter, and had a nice time of it. I would guess that with return visits the whole novelty of the atmosphere and the space might wear off but of course that hasn't happened yet :)
author: Dan C.

description: The wine was good, the server was knowledgeable, the pizza awesome and the building just lovely...but it's always about the company, ain't it?
author: Mi M.

description:
i generally go here a few times a week, and it never disappoints.
the pizzas are good, the antipasti is great, and $10 pitchers of house wine (very decent wine at that) are the best.
this is where i go when i'm in the area and want to grab a bite and hang out for a while.
author: Jaclyn B.

description: Nice spot to stop in for a drink and a nosh.  Great option of having flights of wine.  Service was mediocre, but it is in a great location and a great building, and frankly, I am a fan of some of Mr. Coppola's wines!
author: Danielle R.

description: The building itself is really cool, and the food is good authentic Italian food.
author: Carson H.

description: Great place to stop by for a late lunch or a cup of coffee. The architecture and ambiance are top notch but dont at all take away from great service and food!
author: Mike L.

description: walked up from the hyatt to have dinner here. service was good. quality and quantity of food was good. cleanliness and interior decor was super. definitely will be back. we had wine, absinthe and pasta. next time will save room for the canolis.
author: scott c.

description: While the pizza isn't Tommasso's round the corner, you also don't have the hour long wait for a table. I like the cafe style atmosphere and the food is always pretty good. The service is a little hit and miss (had to ask about 3 times for a Coke), but that just makes it more authentically European in my view.
author: Anthony B.

description: Great place to go for a glass of wine (or a drink) in the afternoon when you are on vacation.  The pizza we had one night was great (very much like those I have had in Rome), and the service is very good.
author: Bill M.

description: We loved this place - the food was great - we chose the dishes the waitress recommended, one pasta dish and one pizza, they where both really good.  The wine was excellent but then the coppola diamond range is one of our favorites, so there was no surprise there.  The staff was very helpful and friendly, and we will be sure to visit again soon.  Also really enjoyed looking at all the pictures and drawings on the walls.
author: Sharon F.

description: This place is really fantastic and their food is double fantastic! My friends and I sat outside in the cold but overhead heaters kept us warm and toasty (there was seating available inside but my friends are smokers, blech!) We were waited on in a timely manner and the waitresses were really professional and friendly always making sure our drinks were full and that we were satisfied with everything. If you're ever in the mood for some great Italian food and hospitality, head on over to Cafe Zoetrope!
author: James F.

description: Yes,  the food is excellent, as is the wine, which is made by Coppola's company. The decor is world class, with the incredible sense of being in Coppola's directorial studio. The service, however, is mixed. On the downside, the blonde manager deserves the "Soup Nazi" award of the year. She refused us service 3 separate times when we arrived 20 to 15 minutes before the posted closing time. No reason given, just, "the kitchen is closed". One other time she charged us for when we asked for a second plate of bread which we though was complimentary.  Great restaurant. Just beware.
author: Dan Z.

description: im sure everyone knows, but, coppola owned.  absolutely outstanding food, ok service, great wine, very cool little place inside, tables outside with heaters above for off-season, place is loaded with pictures of ffc and various other celebs, pretty cool to see. about the only negative would be small portions, but, the food is truly exceptional.
author: John R.

description: Great service, great location, great prices, and a real passion for food. The anipasto plate was epic - every item on it was remarkable. Cheeses, salumi, olives - all fantastic. Pastas were fresh-made and fresh-cut. Pizza was fresh, wood-fired, and delicious. And the house wine was Coppola's Rosso blend, for just $15 a pitcher. We ate outside at one of the heated sidewalk tables (dog friendly), savoring the North Beach twilight and watching the tourists and crazies go by. The check was modest, a terrific value for the money. What a great little cafe.
author: Stuart M.

description: Stumbled into this place after Avertine got to loud to handle.  Lovely!  Had a wonderful red wine and a sampler plate.  Well priced and both were delicious.  The staff was very friendly and were not annoyed that we enjoyed our seats for some time.  The building is beautiful.  A great place to chat as the noise level is just right.
author: Peg S.

description: relaxed euro atmosphere, attentive staff, reasonable wine list, and an excellent antipasto plate. also: ridiculously good balsamic vinegar on the tables - mixed with a little olive oil and the bread - simple and delicious! score the corner booth in the back if you can.
author: Joanna R.

description: Simply put, Café Zoetrope makes me very happy. From the yummy food, drink and amazing staff in the center of the city's universe. Plan to spend hours here people watching and making new friends.
